book.name: eoffer_emod
book.title: eOffer/eMod Help Center
book.body:
Welcome

Welcome to the eOffer/eMod User Help Center! This site has been designed as a guide to introduce you to the eOffer/eMod system. Throughout this Knowledge Base, you will find a step-by-step approach explaining many specific functions within the eOffer/eMod system, as well as information to provide you with a firm understanding of the system as a whole.

Featured Additions

Below are featured articles we would like to bring to your attention.

page.name: introduction
page.title: Introduction
page.body:
Welcome to the eOffer/eMod User Guide! This guide will introduce you to the eOffer/eMod system, a web-based application designed to make the contracting process efficient and secure. The system allows for seamless transmission of data from the Vendor/Contractor community to the Federal Acquisition (FAS) Contracting Offices. This guide is intended for vendors, but can be useful to Contracting Officers (COs) and Contracting Specialists (CSs) as well.

This Guide was written to give an accessible understanding of the different functions of eOffer/eMod to vendors who use the system to submit contract Offers and Contract Modifications. The guide aims to give a comprehensive and easy-to-understand breakdown of the functions of eOffer/eMod, with helpful hints and important reminders along the way.

Revision History

The eOffer/eMod User Guide is updated every three months in concert with GSA's Quarterly Release Cycle. The table below reflects the revision history associated with this document. Note that this document was completely redesigned in December 2011.

page.name: using-the-guide
page.title: Using the Guide
page.body:
The eMod/eOffer User Guide is a searchable and easily navigable manual designed to provide readers with a comprehensive understanding of the eMod/eOffer system. It has also been developed to further the reader's understanding of the contracting process and explain how eOffer/eMod facilitates contracting on the Vendor's side. To continue your learning beyond the information contained in this guide, be sure to consult with your supervisor for additional training opportunities and direction on how to get personalized assistance.

While reading this User Guide, you will notice the following icons throughout:

Helpful Hints: These items provide users with shortcuts or tips on how to better perform a particular action.

Cautions: These items identify potential pitfalls of which the user should be aware.

Key Concepts: These items identify high level attributes or features of a particular program or system.

Things to Remember: These items identify the important points users should take away from a particular section.

If, after searching this User Guide, you still have an unanswered question about the eOffer/eMod system, you may contact the help desk by dialing 866-472-9114 or via e-mail at eoffer@gsa.gov. Their hours of operation are from 8:00 AM to 7:00 PM, Monday through Friday, Eastern Standard Time.

page.name: system-purpose-and-overview
page.title: System Purpose and Overview
page.body:
Under the Schedules Program, Vendors can establish long-term Contracts with GSA that allow them to do business with customers throughout the federal government. In order for Vendors to become a "GSA Schedule Contractor," they must first submit an Offer in response to an applicable Multiple Award Schedule Solicitation. These solicitations are accessible at the Federal Business Opportunities website, (FBO.gov), or, as of 2011, via a link on the eOffer/eMod home page.

Launched in mid-2004, the eMod/eOffer system is a web-based interface allowing Vendors to electronically prepare and submit Contract Offers and Contract Modifications. At a high level, the system allows for an interactive, secure electronic environment that simplifies the Contracting process from Proposal preparation and submission through Contract Award and Closeout.

The eOffer module is available for more than 30 schedules, for example, Furniture (Schedule 71), Office Products and Supplies (Schedule 75), Financial and Business Solutions (Schedule 520), and Professional Engineering Services (Schedule 871).

The eMod module enables Contractors to prepare and submit Electronic Contract Modifications for all GSA MAS Contracts. Multiple eMods may be submitted within a single transaction, allowing for an expeditious process.

The eOffer/eMod system is online at http://eoffer.gsa.gov. Vendors can eSign any Contract Offers or Modifications, but must do so using their Digital Certificates.

The following five characteristics form the core benefits for a Vendor using the eOffer/eMod system:

  • eSimple: User friendly screens lead through the submittal process.

  • eSecure: Digital Certificates ensure the integrity of proprietary data.

  • eSave: Electronic process reduces delivery costs and delays.

  • eShare: Web-based technology facilitates collaboration on Proposal preparation.

  • eSign: Electronic signatures allow offers and mods to be signed quickly and easily.

page.name: eoffer-emod-homepage-overview
page.title: eOffer/eMod Homepage Overview
page.body:
The eOffer/eMod homepage is online at: http://eoffer.gsa.gov/. Within the eMod/eOffer system there are two modules, accessible on the right-hand side of the screen in the box marked "System Access."

  • Contract Offers (eOffers)

  • Contract Modifications (eMods)

Each of these modules serves its own distinct purposes, and this User Guide will illuminate the step-by-step processes associated with each.

Note the System Access options on the right-hand side of the eOffer/eMod homepage.

page.name: additional-help-within-the-system
page.title: Additional Help Within the System
page.body:
The main eOffer/eMod homepage provides numerous helpful links illuminating some of the important features of the eOffer/eMod system. General information about each system and other relevant topics can be found under the About eOffer menu table.

The About eOffer menu table offers background information on the eOffer/eMod system.

Helpful Hint: Within the About eOffer menu section is a subsection titled View Solicitation. Both MAS and Non-MAS Solicitations published to the FedBizOpps website are also available for review here.

The View Solicitations submenu provides access to MAS and Non-MAS Solicitations that have been published to FedBizOpps.

Included in the Before you Begin menu table are short reminder checklists that can be used to ensure you, the vendor, are ready to submit an eOffer or eMod. These checklists represent baseline lists of criteria that need to be satisfied before submitting either an eOffer or an eMod.

Consult the Before you Begin menu table for useful checklists pertaining to the submission of an eOffer or eMod.

page.name: help-desk-and-points-of-contact
page.title: Help Desk and Points of Contact
page.body: For further questions or suggestions about eOffer/eMod, users may contact General Services Administration by calling 1-866-472-9114 (8:00 am - 7:00 pm (EST) Monday through Friday) or by sending an email to eoffer@gsa.gov. For solicitation/contract-related issues and questions, vendors should contact the representative listed in the solicitation, or their GSA Contracting Official.

page.name: accessing-eoffer-emod-overview
page.title: Accessing eOffer/eMod Overview
page.body: eOffer/eMod is a publicly available system; it does not reside behind GSA's firewall. Therefore, eOffer/eMod is available to any internet user via the URL, http://eoffer.gsa.gov/. Having said that, most of the functionality discussed in this Guide involves signing into a secure portion of the website, and there are a few key requirements that need to be satisfied in order for a vendor to actually use the system once signed in.

page.name: system-requirements
page.title: System Requirements
page.body:
In order to ensure the integrity and security of the eOffer/eMod system, four key requirements must be met before a vendor can put the system to use. eOffer/eMod uses the latest digital authentication technology to ensure the integrity of data transmission, and to support the security of electronic signatures applied to Offer or Contract Modifications.

In order to log into the system, the following requirements must be met:

  1. Digital Certificate: A Digital Certificate is an electronic credential stored on the web browser that verifies the user's identity. It is required before a vendor is granted access to the eOffer/eMod system.

  2. Data Universal Numbering System (DUNS) Number: The DUNS number is a unique nine digit identification number assigned to a business entity by Dun and Bradstreet. A valid DUNS number is required to use the eOffer/eMod system.

  3. System for Award Management (SAM): To use the eOffer/eMod system, users must have a DUNS number that is registered in the SAM database.

  4. "Pathway to Success" Training: The final requirement for participation in the MAS Schedules Program is successful completion of the "Pathway to Success" educational seminar.

page.name: digital-certificates-overview
page.title: Digital Certificates Overview
page.body:
In order to successfully sign into the functional areas of eOffer/eMod, a Digital certificate must be present and valid on the user's computer. In basic terms, Digital Certificates are electronic credentials that:

  • Assert the identity of an individual.

  • Enable eOffer/eMod to verify the identity of the individual accessing the system and signing documents.

  • Encrypt or decrypt data to ensure that it is securely transmitted.

  • Store accurate information directly within a web browser or within a token.

  • Create digital signatures that are verifiable.

A Digital Signature:

Is Is Not

  • A piece of information based on both the document and the signer's private key.

  • A digitized handwritten signature.

  • Unique to both the document and the signer.

  • The typed name of an individual

  • Virtually impossible to forge

  • A secret code, password, or PIN.

Key Concept: Each individual accessing the eOffer/eMod system must have a Digital Certificate installed on his or her computer. Digital Certificates are unique to each person and cannot be used by another individual or a group.

page.name: obtaining-a-digital-certificate
page.title: Obtaining a Digital Certificate
page.body:
As previously noted, a Digital Certificate is required before an individual vendor is able to use most any functional portion of the eOffer/eMod system. If you do not currently have a Digital Certificate installed on your computer, the steps below will help you obtain one, and ultimately allow you to begin working with eOffer/eMod.

  1. To apply for a Digital Certificate, go to the eOffer/eMod website, http://eoffer.gsa.gov.

  2. Under the About eOffer menu table, click on the link for Digital Certificates.

    3. Click the Digital Certificates link under the About eOffer menu table.

  3. You will be presented with a page giving you an overview of Digital Certificate information. Under the heading, "How to get a digital certificate," click either the IdenTrust or Operational Research Consultants (ORC) link to visit a Digital Certificates provider.

    4. Select one of the Certificate providers.

  4. For example, if you click the IdenTrust link, you will be taken to IdenTrust's GSA Certification Procurement page. To begin, click 'Buy.'

    Alternatively, if you click the Operational Research Consultants (ORC) link, you will be taken to the ORC homepage. There, you will see an Order button for ACES Business Representative Certificates.

    For either provider, the Certificate purchase process will require proof of employment and two forms of government issued identification.

    5. Key Concept: The information you enter while purchasing a Digital Certificate must match exactly the information that will be used within the eOffer/eMod system. The Certificate application should also be completed on the same workstation that will be used to accept the Certificate.

  5. Whichever Certificate provider you choose, make sure you remember your password! Neither the GSA nor your Digital Certificate provider can tell you what your password is should you forget it, in which case you will be forced to buy another Certificate.

    6. Things to Remember: Your Digital Certificate must be an ACES Level 3 Certificate, (a "Business Identity Certificate"). Without this level of authentication, vendors will not be able to create a legally binding Contract. As noted in this topic, the industry partners who currently provide Level 3 Digital Authentication Certificates for the GSA vendor community are IdenTrust and Operational Research Consultants (ORC). DOD ECA Certificates are acceptable.

page.name: importing-the-digital-certificate-into-your-browser
page.title: Importing the Digital Certificate into Your Browser
page.body:
Once you have received your Digital Certificate, you will need to install it within your web browser. The following are instructions for Digital Certificate installation on Microsoft Internet Explorer.

  1. In Microsoft Internet Explorer, open the Tools dropdown menu and select 'Internet Options.'

    2. Select 'Internet Options' from the Tools dropdown menu.

  2. In the Internet Options window, select the Content tab.

    3. Select the Content Tab.

  3. In the Content tab, click the Certificates button.

    4. Click the Certificates button.

  4. The Certificates window should open with the Personal tab selected as a default; from here, click the Import button. Doing so will launch the Certificate Import Wizard.

    5. Click 'Import' within the Personal tab of the Certificates window.

  5. Click 'Next' once the Certificate Import Wizard launches.

    6. Click 'Next' in the Certificate Import Wizard.

  6. In the following screen, click the Browse button below the File to Import prompt in order to find the Certificate file you wish to upload.

    7. Click 'Browse' to search for your Certificate.

  7. You will have already saved your Certificate on your computer or on another local drive. Navigate to the location of the Certificate and select it so that the name appears in the File name field at the bottom of the window. To facilitate this process, you may use the dropdown menu to the right to filter visible files by the Personal Information Exchange (.pfx) extension.

    Click 'Open' once you have found and selected the correct Certificate file.

    8. Select the correct Certificate file, then click 'Open.'

  8. The field below the File to Import prompt will now show the name of the Certificate file you have selected. Click 'Next' to proceed.

    9. Click 'Next' to proceed once you have selected the correct file.

  9. You must now enter the password you chose when you obtained your Digital Certificate. After you have entered your password, check the security option(s) best suited to your uses, then click 'Next.'

    10. Helpful Hint: Note that you are presented three security options on this particular screen; you may choose any combination of these according to the arrangement best suited to your purposes. For guidance, consult your Supervisor. As a default, in our example we have enabled the third option, Include all extended properties.

    Enter your password, make your security selections, then click 'Next.'

  10. The next screen of the Certificate Import Wizard should default to the option, Place all certificates in the following store, in response to which you will make sure the Certificate store field reads, 'Personal.' If it does not, click the Browse button to select 'Personal' from the available Certificate Store directory. When you have made your selection, click 'Next.'

    11. Be sure the Certificate store field reads, 'Personal.'

  11. The next screen will present a summary of your previous selections. By default, information in the settings window may be highlighted, but there is no information in need of change on this screen. If any of the information displayed here is incorrect, click 'Back' to revisit previous steps. Otherwise, check that the settings are correct, then click the Finish button to proceed.

    12. Click 'Finish' after confirming settings information is correct.

  12. Click 'Okay' when informed that the import was successful.

    13. Click 'OK' after a successful import.

  13. You will now see your Certificate in the Certificates window. Click the Close button.

    14. Click 'Close' to close the Certificates window.

    Helpful Hint: You may return to the Certificates window later on to Remove a Certificate if need be. Or, provided the functionality is enabled, you may also Export your Certificate from this location.

  14. Click 'OK' to close the Internet Options window.

Click 'OK' to close the Internet Options window.

page.name: verifying-information-on-the-digital-certificate
page.title: Verifying Information on the Digital Certificate
page.body:
Once your Digital Certificate is installed and you have backed it up, it is a good idea to verify that all the information is accurate. We are demonstrating this process using Internet Explorer.

  1. In Microsoft Internet Explorer, open the Tools menu and select 'Internet Options.'

    2. Select 'Internet options' from the Tools dropdown menu.

  2. In the Content tab of the Internet Options window, click the 'Certificates' button.

    3. In the Content Tab, click 'Certificates.'

  3. The Certificates window should open by default to the Personal tab. In this tab, you will see any Certificates previously imported into the browser. Select the Certificate whose information you would like to verify, then click 'View.'

    4. Select the Certificate and click 'View.'

  4. In the Details tab you will find a directory containing various Fields of Digital Certificate information. Clicking on these Fields displays the value in the window below the directory listing. To verify the name associated with the Digital Certificate, click on the Subject field.

    5. In the Details tab, click on the Subject field to verify your name.

  5. In order to verify the email address associated with the Digital Certificate, click on the Subject Alternative Name field.

    6. Confirm your email address is correct by clicking the Subject Alternative Name field.

  6. Finally, go to the Certification Path tab to verify the path location of your Certificate.

    7. Verify the path location of your Certificate within the Certification Path tab.

    Helpful Hint: The Certificate status box in the Certification Path tab will indicate whether there are any problems associated with your Digital Certificate.

page.name: system-validation-of-the-digital-certificate
page.title: System Validation of the Digital Certificate
page.body:
Digital Certificates are required by Contractor staff in order to access the eOffer/eMod system. Upon logging into the system, Digital Certificate information is validated against the Authorized Negotiators on a Contract.

To begin, click on the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers) or Contract Modification (eMod). When a user accesses either of the modules, there can be one of several outcomes:

  • The user's digital certificate is validated against the list of Authorized Negotiators on a Contract and the user is granted access.

  • Either the user has never been listed as an Authorized Negotiator because the original Offer was submitted by Paper and thus the user was never added to the electronic system, or the old Negotiator has left the Company at which point they are trying to get a new Negotiator listed in the table.

  • The user was in the Authorized Negotiator list and has either changed his or her name, or gotten a new Digital Certificate without listing his or her details as on the Authorized Negotiator list. Or the person who initially submitted the vendor's information entered it into the system differently than how it was listed on their Digital Certificate.

If the user's login attempt falls into either of the last two scenarios, the system will attempt to validate by using certain combinations of user details. If a potential match is found in the Contract's list of Authorized Negotiators, the user will be able to select his or her information from a list provided, and then submit that information to the existing Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators for approval. If the existing Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators do not take an action with seven days to approve the new addition, the request is then sent to the CO/CS for approval. The vendor's details are then transferred to the Authorized Negotiators/Contract Administrators, or to the CO/CS, for approval.

The validation combinations include:

  • Last name and email.

    • Validation by last name and email.

  • First name and email.

    • Validation by first name and email.

  • Email only.

    • Validation by email only.

  • Last name and first name only.

    • Validation by last and first name only.

  • Last name only.

    • Validation by last name only.

  • First name only.

    • Validation by first name only.

Digital Certificate Match Found

If the system finds a match using one of the above validation combinations:

  1. Select your name from the list.

  2. Click 'Initiate Request,' which will trigger an email notifying one of the other Authorized Negotiators on the Contract, instructing him or her to submit a modification updating the information of the original Authorized Negotiator. If an Authorized Negotiator is not found, the Request is sent to the CO/CS.

  3. The Authorized Negotiator, or CO/CS, to whom the Request is sent will then log into the system and will be prompted to confirm adding the user to the Contract.

    4. Digital Certificate match found.

Note that if the Authorized Negotiator does not respond with a modification within seven (7) days, the system will notify the Contracting Officer to initiate a modification to update the Authorized Negotiator Data.

Digital Certificate Not Found

If your Digital Certificate is not found by any combination of validation criteria, you will be prompted to complete an application to be added to the list of Authorized Negotiators.

  1. Fill out the fields provided and click 'Submit Request.' Note that the Name and Email fields are pulled directly from the system in order to avoid any typing errors.

    2. Digital Certificate match not found.

  2. An email will be sent to the Authorized Negotiator or, in the case that one cannot be found, to the CO/CS for approval.

    3. An email will be sent to the Authorized Negotiator or CO/CS for approval.

page.name: data-universal-number-system-duns-number
page.title: Data Universal Number System (DUNS) Number
page.body:
A Data Universal Number System, or DUNS number, is a unique nine-digit identification number assigned to a business entity by Dun & Bradstreet. It is required to use the eOffer/eMod system, and also needed when registering with the SAM database. The DUNS number assignment is free for all businesses required to register with the U.S. Federal Government for Contracts or Grants.

Obtaining a DUNS Number

To obtain a DUNS number:

  1. Go to http://fedgov.dnb.com/webform

  2. A Dun & Bradstreet webform will open.

    3. The Dun & Bradstreet webform.

  3. Click the option to request the DUNS number via the web and follow the instructions.

page.name: system-for-award-management-sam
page.title: System for Award Management (SAM)
page.body:
The Central Contractor Registration (CCR)/Federal Agency Registration (FedReg), the Online Representations and Certifications Applications (ORCA), and several other databases have been integrated into a single system to create a streamlined process for entities to register with the Federal Government, (formerly CCR/FedReg), and complete representations and Certifications (formerly ORCA). The System for Award Management, or SAM, is now the primary registrant database for the U.S. Federal Government. SAM collects, validates, and stores entity data in support of Agency Acquisition missions. A vendor must be registered with SAM prior to the Award of a Schedule Contract. Additionally, a DUNS number is required when registering with SAM.

Registering with SAM (SAM)

To register with SAM you must first create a User Account. Note that if you were previously registered with CCR and ORCA, your old login will not work in this system.

  1. Go to the SAM homepage: https://www.sam.gov/portal/public/SAM/.

  2. Click 'Create User Account.'

    3. Key Concept: The term "entity" is new in the realm of Federal Contracting. SAM is an integrated system with which several user communities interface, including vendors, Grantees, and Federal Agencies. In order to identify these varied users by one name, with regard to SAM, GSA refers to these users as "entities."

    On the System For Award Management (SAM) homepage, click 'Create User Account.'

  3. Next, you will be prompted to choose either an Account type. Under Individual Account Details, choose 'Create an Account.'

    4. Click 'Create an Account.'

  4. Follow the on-screen directions and fill out the Personal Information form fields. Click 'Next' to continue.

    5. Fill in your Personal Information.

  5. Next, complete the Account Information fields; this will include choosing a new username. It is important to note that once this username is created, it cannot be changed. After you are finished, click 'Next.'

    6. Fill in the Account Information.

  6. The next screen offers you a chance to review the data that you have entered and finalize the account creation. When you are ready to proceed, click 'Submit.' Unfortunately, the screens to show this step are too long to include. You may visit www.sam.gov and click the Help link to access a library of demonstration videos specific to SAM.

  7. Lastly, a screen will appear that confirms your account creation. An email will be sent to the address that you specified, detailing further instructions for completing the account creation process. Note that you must complete the confirmation process within 48 hours; after that, the entire process will need to be restarted.

    8. The confirmation screen.

  8. Click 'Done' to return to the SAM homepage where you may log in to the system after completing the final validation.

page.name: pathway-to-success-training
page.title: Pathway to Success Training
page.body:
Pathway to Success is designed to assist prospective GSA Schedule Contractors in making informed business decisions as to whether obtaining a GSA Schedule Contract is in their best interest. The presentation provides background information on the GSA Schedules Program and encompasses a variety of other topics including:

  1. GSA's expectations for a vendor to become a successful Schedule Contractor.

  2. Competing as a GSA Schedule Contractor in the government marketplace.

  3. Developing a GSA Schedule-specific business plan.

  4. Submitting a quality Offer, the Proposal submission process, and the GSA Schedule Solicitation.

Vendors may attend either a live presentation or complete web-based training at the vendor Support Center by visiting, http://vsc.gsa.gov, and selecting the Education tab.

The GSA vendor Support website.

page.name: logging-in
page.title: Logging In
page.body:
Once you have fulfilled all of the previously discussed requirements, you are ready to begin using the system. The homepage for eOffer and eMod is located at www.eoffer.gsa.gov.

When you go to the site you will find the Sign In buttons to the two systems on the right-hand side. Both systems have the same initial log in. For this example, we will assume this is the first time you have visited the site, and that you wish to log into the eOffer system.

  1. To begin, click on the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    2. Click the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    Key Concept: It is important to note at this point that users should not use the "Back" button in their web browsers. Doing so will cause data to be lost in the process. Use the buttons at the bottom of each screen, or click on different menu options to maneuver through the process.

  2. Upon first logging into the eOffer/eMod system, you will be required to verify your Digital Authentication Certificate. A dialogue box will open showing the existing Certifications on your system. Select the appropriate Certificate and click 'OK.'

    3. Verify your Digital Certificate.

  3. Click 'OK' on the Private Exchange Key or Windows Security pop-up screen to allow your browser to recognize your Certification.

  4. The sign in screen requires you to enter your Data Universal Numbering System (DUNS) number.

    1. If you have previously accessed the eOffer/eMod system, your DUNS number should be available from the dropdown menu in the Select previously entered DUNS field.

    2. If you have not previously used the eOffer/eMod system, you'll need to manually enter your DUNS number.

      3. Key Concept: The DUNS PLUS 4 field is optional. It is an extension of a DUNS number created by registrants in SAM when there is a need for more than one bank/Electronic Funds Transfer (EFT) account for a particular location. Basically the "DUNS plus 4" designation is used to identify specific business units within the overall organizational hierarchy.

      Enter your DUNS number.

  5. Click 'Submit' when finished entering in a new DUNS or selecting an appropriate, previously used DUNS number.

    6. Caution: If the DUNS number is incorrect or has expired an error message will display. You should contact the Federal Service Desk for SAM customer service at www.fsd.gov or 866-606-8220.

  6. Once the DUNS number has been validated the eOffer application will be accessed, displaying the MY eOFFERS page.

    7. This is the My eOffers page.

    Key Concept: The "My eOffers" screen serves as the entry point to the eOffer system. You can review all of the offers that have been processed to various extents, (Saved, Submitted, Signed).

page.name: preparing-your-electronic-contract-offer-eoffer-overview
page.title: Preparing Your Electronic Contract Offer (eOffer) Overview
page.body:
The web-based application eOffer allows Companies to electronically prepare and submit a Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) Contract Proposal to GSA's Federal Acquisition Service. It creates an interactive and secure electronic environment that simplifies the Contracting process from submission of Proposals all the way through Contract Award.

In the past, a vendor's submission of a Contract Offer relied heavily on paper-based processes. Vendors would print a bunch of forms, compile their Offers, and mail them in to GSA. Email helped expedite the process somewhat, but GSA still lacked a centralized system capable of handing the entirety of the Offer process.

eOffer, introduced in May 2004, has become the preferred method by which Contract Offers are submitted to GSA. This system is available for use on most of GSA's Multiple Award Schedules (MAS). With a friendly user interface and advanced functionality, eOffer has become an important tool for GSA as well as the vendor community.

page.name: preliminary-steps-before-using-the-system
page.title: Preliminary Steps Before Using the System
page.body:
The Offer process has several basic steps that must be completed outside of the system before you can use eOffer.

  1. Download and read the Solicitation that you are making an Offer against, and complete the required documents for that Solicitation. The Solicitations available for eOffers have recently been published to the system directly. You can access all of the solicitation documents here or by searching for them on FBO.gov.

  2. Gather your Company information and create the required documents for the Solicitation before starting to complete the information in eOffer. Once this has been done, you can enter the eOffer Application (which requires a Digital Certificate for authentication), prepare the responses to the Offer and submit your Proposal.

page.name: creating-a-contract-offer-eoffer
page.title: Creating a Contract Offer (eOffer)
page.body:
To sign into the eOffer application and create an Offer, follow these steps:

  1. Go to the GSA eOffer/eMod homepage.

  2. Click the Sign In button under Contract Offers (eOffers).

    3. Key Concept: The system is accessed via Digital Certificate authentication. For detailed login information, see the section on System Requirements to Access eOffer/eMod.

  3. After a successful login, the Sign In page will appear.

  4. If you have previously entered your DUNS number, select it using the dropdown menu. If entering a new DUNS number, type it in the field below and click Submit. The MY eOFFERS screen will load.

    5. Select your DUNS number and click Submit.

  5. Select a Solicitation number against which the Offer will be submitted. This is found in the dropdown menu under Schedule Solicitation.

    6. Select the Solicitation and click 'Submit Online.'

  6. If this is a new Offer under a new Solicitation, you will be taken to the Corporate Information screen, in which case continue to the Confirming Your Corporate Information section. However, if a Contract or Offer already exists under the chosen Solicitation, an informational message like this one will appear:

    7. An Informational Message will appear if a Contract or Offer Already Exists under the current solicitation.

page.name: confirming-your-corporate-information
page.title: Confirming Your Corporate Information
page.body:
The Corporate Information page will be displayed with details pulled directly from the System for Award Management (SAM) database.

  1. Verify that all information on the Corporate Information screen is correct.

    2. Verify your Corporate Information.

    Helpful Hint: The "View PDF" link at the top of the screen will launch the Solicitation document if you need to review the Contract requirements.

  2. If the information is correct, click Save and Continue to move forward.

    3. Caution: If any information on the Corporate Information screen is not correct, click the Sign Out and Correct Errors in CCR button. This will return you to the eOffer/eMod homepage. To access the CCR, follow the link Have you registered with CCR and with Orca? under the "Before You Begin" section. After corrections are made, the eOffer/eMod system will update in approximately 24 hours. Note that that all links that refer to CCR will now redirect to the System for Award Management (SAM). For more information on SAM, refer to their website at www.sam.gov, or see the Registering with the System for Award Management section in this Guide.

  3. The Information Saved screen will appear, indicating that the Corporate Information has been completed (note its corresponding green check mark in left-side menu). Click on Continue; this will take you to the Add Negotiator(s) screen.

    4. Caution: Do not use the "Back" button on the browser toolbar since it may lead to loss of data. Use the buttons at the bottom of each screen, or click on sections under the Prepare your eOffer menu on the left to maneuver through the process.

    Click Continue at the Information Saved message.

page.name: adding-your-negotiators
page.title: Adding Your Negotiators
page.body:
All users who need to access the system to work on a particular eOffer will need to be added as Authorized Negotiators. Multiple Negotiators may be added at one time, if necessary. The Negotiator's name and email address must be entered exactly as they appear on the individual's Digital Certificate.

Note that it is important to have more than one Negotiator assigned to a Contract. In the event that one Negotiator is unavailable, you will have another assigned to the Contract to ensure that a representative from your Company can still sign off on agreements with the government.

Additionally, as of February 2012, all Negotiators on a Contract have been provided "Global Read Capabilities." This means that no matter who has started a Contract Offer or Modification Request, an Authorized Negotiator will have the ability to create, submit, and edit offers and modification requests.

  1. To add a Negotiator, complete the mandatory fields as indicated by an asterisk (*), including Name, Title, Phone, and Email.

    2. Fill out the contact information for the Negotiator you are adding.

  2. Select a Role you want to assign to this Negotiator and click Add This Negotiator.

    3. Helpful Hint: A Negotiator can be assigned one of two roles; one denotes the Negotiator is authorized to sign and one denotes the Negotiator is not authorized to sign. A Negotiator who is "Authorized to Sign" is capable of providing his or her Digital Certificate for the benefit of any Offers or Mods. In essence, this person has been granted the authority to bind the Company into agreements with GSA. Someone who is not authorized to sign, however, may prepare an Offer, but will not be allowed to sign or submit it. Note that there should be at least one Negotiator who is authorized to sign.

    Select the Role for your negotiator and click 'Add This Negotiator.'

  3. Once a Negotiator is added, he or she will be listed under Your Negotiators. If you need to add another Negotiator, click Add New Negotiator and repeat the steps above.

    4. Helpful Hint: Many Contractors rely on third party consultants to help prepare Offers. Note that it is up to you whether or not you want to grant signing authority to a consultant in this situation. It is not a determination made by GSA.

    Click 'Add New Negotiator' to add additional Negotiators.

  4. A Negotiator can also be deleted, or their information can be edited. Use the Edit and Delete links provided under the Actions column as needed. Once all the Negotiators have been added, click Save and Continue.

    5. You can edit or delete your Negotiators; when finished, click 'Save and Continue.'

  5. The Information Saved screen will display a message indicating the Negotiator section is complete. Click Continue to move on to the next section.

    6. Click 'Continue' at the Information Saved message.

page.name: adding-your-goods-and-services-sins
page.title: Adding Your Goods and Services (SINs)
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/goods-service/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_goods_services.mp4

After adding your Negotiators, the Goods/Services page is your next destination. This step involves choosing the Special Item Number(s) (SINs) to be included in the offer. The SIN is the identifier for the type of Goods or Services being provided. Each offer may contain multiple SINs.

Helpful Hint: SINs are subgroups of similar Products and Services found under a particular Schedule. More information on individual SINs can be obtained from the GSA eLibrary.

Your answers in this section will determine the outputs for the rest of this process. Your selections here will appear in the left-hand column, and will require further completion.

  1. For grouped SINs, use the Select SIN group drop-down menu to choose the specific SIN group you wish to add.

    2. For grouped SINs, choose the group from the dropdown menu.

  2. For grouped SINs, click the Select SIN Group button.

    3. For grouped SINs, click the Select SIN Group button.

  3. A new drop-down will appear. Select your SIN from the drop-down menu.

    4. Select your SIN.

  4. Click the Add SIN Details button.

    5. Click the Add SIN Details button.

  5. Select the NAICS Code from the drop-down menu. You may have many options to choose from, and you should select the NAICS Code that is the closest match to the Service you are providing.

    6. Helpful Hint: Selecting the most applicable NAICS Code can be tricky. For more information on individual NAICS codes, visit www.census.gov/eos/www/naics.

    Select the NAICS code.

  6. Select the Scope that pertains to your delivery practices from the drop-down menu.

    7. Select the SIN scope.

  7. Enter your company's total projected annual sales to the Government under this SIN in the Estimated Sales field.

    8. Enter your company's total projected annual Government sales for the SIN.

  8. Respond to the Commercial Delivery Schedule question by clicking the appropriate radio button.

    1. If you answer "No" to this question, you are required to enter when delivery will occur in number of days after receipt of order.

    9. Respond to the Commercial Delivery Schedule.

  9. Enter the expedited delivery time (in days) in the provided text box.

    10. Enter the expedited delivery time (in days).

  10. Click the Add This SIN button.

    11. Click the Add This SIN button.

  11. You will be taken back to the Goods and Services main page where you will see your SIN details added to the Your SIN(s) table.

    12. You will see your SIN details added to the table.

  12. Use the drop-down menu to make the appropriate selection for the Preponderance of Work.

    13. Select the Preponderance of Work.

  13. Click the Add Preponderance of Work button.

    14. Click the Add Preponderance of Work button.

  14. You will see your selection added to the table below the drop-down menu.

    15. You will see the Preponderance of Work in the table below.

  15. Within Offer Category, make the appropriate selection based on what you are offering:

    • Products Only: You are offering only products under your SIN.

    • Services Only: You are offering only services under your SIN.

    • Products and Services: You are offering both products and services under your SIN.

    16. Select your offer category.

  16. After making your selection, click Save and Continue.

    17. Click Save and Continue.

page.name: wizard-management-overview
page.title: Wizard Management Overview
page.body:
Wizard Management allows you to customize the fields that will appear on your template. This section includes methods for entering details for product-related line items, uploading additional photos, generating an offer analysis report, and generating pricing documents. This section will appear only when you choose Products Only or Products and Services within the offer category.

Wizard Management constitutes the following components: Discounts, Delivery, Contractor Warranty, Zonal Pricing, Special Charges, Special Features, Accessories, Options, and Photos.

Select the categories that apply to your offer.

page.name: product-template-wizard
page.title: Product Template Wizard
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/wizard_management_lesson

book Instructions

Helpful Hint: Selections made on this screen will be visible on the left-hand menu and as tabs in the Capture Pricing table, and will affect subsequent steps in the offer process. If you select Accessories or Options, these sections will not be visible on the left panel, however, they will be captured within your final template.

  1. Using the drop-down menus, select Yes for the categories that apply to your offer. Delivery will automatically be selected for you as it is a mandatory field. Categories include: Discounts, Delivery, Contractor Warranty, Zonal Pricing, Special Charges, Special Features, Accessories, Options, and Photos.

    Select the categories that apply to your offer.

  2. For the Discounts and Delivery categories, you must also select the level (Offer Level, SIN Level, or Line Item Level) at which they will be applied.

    3. Select the level for your and Discount and Delivery categories.

  3. Click the Save Wizard Responses button before you click Save and Continue. If you do not click this button first, your data will be lost.

    4. Helpful Hint: You must click Save Wizard Responses before clicking Save and Continue or your entires will be lost.

    Click Save Wizard Responses BEFORE you hit Save and Continue.

  4. Click the Save and Continue button.

    5. Click Save and Continue second.

  5. Your left-hand navigational menu will change based on the selections you made in this section. Based on your personal selections, your screen may look different than what is presented below.

Your left-hand navigation will reflect your Wizard Management selections.

page.name: zonal-pricing
page.title: Zonal Pricing
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/zonal_pricing_lesson

book Instructions

If you selected "Yes" to Zonal Pricing on the Wizard Management screen, you are required to fill out this section. The Zonal Pricing section allows you to define your pricing based on zones you define.

The Zonal Pricing screen allows you to define your pricing based on zones that you define.

  1. First, select a zone number between 01-10 using the Enter Zone Number drop-down menu.

    2. Select your first Zone number.

  2. Select the zonal area. "CONUS" indicates the contiguous United States.

    1. Each state in CONUS will automatically be checked. Uncheck any box(es) next to the state(s) that do not apply to the zonal area you are creating.

    3. CONUS is the contiguous United States.

  3. Click the Add Zone button.

    4. Click the Add Zone button.

  4. You will see your zone added to the List of Zones table.

    5. The zone you just defined will appear in the List of Zones table below.

  5. "NON-CONUS" indicates non-contiguous US states and territories. To add these territories, select a zone area that is different from the one(s) you have already created and click the radio button next to NON-CONUS.

    6. NON-CONUS indicates non-contiguous US states and territories.

  6. Repeat steps 3 and 4.

  7. Ensure that each state, both CONUS and NON-CONUS, is represented by a zonal area.

    8. Ensure all states and territories are accounted for by your zones.

  8. When you have entered all of your zones, click the Save and Continue button.

    9. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

page.name: special-charges
page.title: Special Charges
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/special_charges_lesson

book Instructions

If you selected "Yes" to Special Charges on the Wizard Management screen, you will be required to complete this section.

The Special Charges screen is where you account for any non-standard charges for your products.

  1. Within the Special Charges screen, first choose the SIN to which these charges apply using the SIN drop-down menu.

    2. Choose your SIN.

  2. Click the Select button.

    3. Click Select.

  3. Check the boxes for the charges that apply to your SIN.

    4. Check the applicable charges for your SIN.

  4. Click the Add Special Charges button.

    5. Click Add Special Charges.

  5. You will see the item(s) you have chosen in a table at the bottom of your screen.

    6. Your Special Charges will appear in the table below.

  6. Click the Save And Continue button.

    7. Click Save and Continue.

page.name: special-features
page.title: Special Features
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/special_features_lesson

book Instructions

If you selected "Yes" to Special Features on the Wizard Management screen, you are required to complete this section. Here, you will select your Environmental and Special Features that will be incorporated into your final template.

Special Features allows you to account for environmental features and non-standard product features.

  1. Within the Special Features screen, first choose the SIN to which these features apply using the drop-down menu.

    2. Select your SIN.

  2. Click the Select button.

    3. Click the Select button.

  3. Check the boxes for the features that apply to your SIN under both the Environmental Features and Special Features headings.

    4. Check the applicable environmental and special features for your SIN.

  4. Click the Add Special Features button.

    5. Click Add Special Features.

  5. You will see the item(s) you have chosen in a table at the bottom of your screen.

    6. Your selections will appear in the table below.

  6. Click the Save and Continue button.

    7. Click Save and Continue.

page.name: discounts
page.title: Discounts
page.body:
If you selected "Yes" to Discounts on the Wizard Management screen, you are required to complete this section.

In this section, you will need to enter the discount(s) you offer under your selected SIN. You will need to enter the start and end range for the discount, as well as the percentage. You can add multiple discounts, but only one at a time.

  1. Within the Create Discount table, you will see a field called Start Range. This indicates the minimum number of items (greater than 1) that need to be ordered to initiate a discount.

    2. Begin by defining the start to your Discount quantity range.

  2. Next, fill in the text box for End Range. This indicates the maximum number of items ordered to fulfill a discount.

    3. Enter the end range for your discount range.

  3. Enter the Discount % you will offer.

    4. Enter the discount percentage.

  4. If you have any discount conditions, add them in the text box.

    5. Enter the discount conditions of the range you defined.

  5. Click the Add Discount button.

    6. Click Add Discount.

  6. Your discount will be added to the Discount Listing table at the bottom of the screen.

    7. The Discount will appear below.

  7. Click the Save & Continue button.

    8. Click Save and Continue.

  8. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    9. Click the Continue button.

page.name: contractor-warranty
page.title: Contractor Warranty
page.body:
If you selected "Yes" to Contractor Warranty on the Wizard Management screen, you will need to complete this section.

In this section, you will indicate the details of the Contractor Warranty offered under your SIN. Here, you will enter the warranty period and, if applicable, a description of the warranty.

  1. First, select your SIN from the drop-down menu.

    2. Select your SIN.

  2. Select the Warranty Period (day, month, year, or lifetime).

    3. Select your Warranty Period.

  3. Next, enter the Number of Warranty Periods in the text box. This indicates the period that the warranty covers. The Number of Warranty Periods will automatically be populated with "None" if "Lifetime" is selected.

    4. Enter the number of warranty periods.

  4. Enter your Warranty Description (if applicable).

    5. Enter the Warranty Description.

  5. Click the Add Contractor Warranty button.

    6. Click Add Contractor Warranty.

  6. Your warranty information will be displayed in a table at the bottom of your screen.

    7. Your warranty information will appear in a table.

  7. Click the Save and Continue button.

    8. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

  8. On the Information Saved screen, click the Continue button.

    9. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

page.name: capture-and-generate-pricing-overview
page.title: Capture and Generate Pricing Overview
page.body:
Before you make your selection for a pricing template, you must have completed each section on your left-hand navigational menu. When you are ready to enter your pricing data, you have three templates from which to choose. The method you select is dependent upon the number of items you need to enter, and your preference to work on or offline.

On this screen, you will see three options: Download/Upload Template, On-Screen Data Entry, and Electronic Data Interchange (EDI).

A look at the Capture and Generate Pricing main screen.

page.name: choosing-a-pricing-template-method
page.title: Choosing a Pricing Template Method
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/choosing_pricing_template_lesson

book Instructions

  1. Choose your method for entering details for product-related line items.

    1. Download/Upload Template

      • This method allows you to download an Excel template created by the system and work on it offline. After entering your data, you will need to upload the file back into the system to validate against any errors. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.

        • Download a template.

    2. On-Screen Data Entry

      • This method allows you enter product information into the template within the system. You are required to be online while working in this template. This method is best for entering fewer than 100 items.

        • Enter your data online.

    3. Electronic Data Interchange (EDI)

      • This method allows you to download a template created by the system and work on it offline. You will be required to generate a transaction key and use it in the EDI system to upload your files. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.

        • Work on a template offline.

  2. Select the pricing template that best suits your needs by clicking on the button under the option you choose.

page.name: download-template-overview
page.title: Download/Upload Template Overview
page.body:
This method will allow you to download the template created by the system so that you can work on it offline. Upon completing, you will need to upload the file that you have worked on. The downloaded template will not be updated automatically if any changes are made on the screen related to Wizard Management. If you make changes, you must download, complete, and upload the template again.

This is the best selection if you are entering more than 100 items.

Click Proceed to Download/Upload Template.

page.name: downloading-your-template
page.title: Downloading Your Template
page.body:
Before you can begin entering your pricing data, you must first download the Excel template created by the system.

  1. Click on the Proceed to Download Template button on the Product Template Method main screen.

    2. Click the Proceed to Download Template button.

  2. Click the Download button to download a template created by the system to your computer.

    3. Click the Download button.

  3. Click on the download to open the Excel spreadsheet.

    4. Click on the download.

page.name: reference-tabs
page.title: Reference Tabs
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below for step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/download_reference_tabs_lesson

book Instructions

On these tabs, you will find lists of names and codes for various fields, including but not limited to Production Points, Unit of Issue, Special Features, and Delivery. You will need to refer to these tabs when completing these fields in the Download/Upload Template Excel spreadsheet.

  1. The Code Lookup tab contains codes related to Production Point, Unit of Issue, and Special Features.

    2. The Code Lookup tab.

    1. Production Point

      1. To locate the code you will need to enter, first refer to the Production Point Name column and locate the country in which your product/accessory was manufactured. For this example, we will use the country of Belgium.

        2. The Production Point Name column.

      2. Directly to the left of "Belgium" is that country's corresponding code, which you will see is "BE."

        3. After locating the name of your Production Point, find its corresponding code.

      3. You will then copy "BE" and paste it into the appropriate cell in another tab.

    2. Unit of Issue:

      1. A Unit of Issue describes in what format, quantity, or packaging a product will be sold. To locate the code you will need to enter, first refer to the Unit of Issue Name column. For example, to locate the code for 100-PACK, first find that under the Unit of Issue Name column.

        2. The Unit of Issue Name column.

      2. Directly to the left of "100-PACK" is that unit's corresponding code, which you will see is "4F."

        3. After locating your Unit of Issue, find its corresponding code.

      3. You will then copy "4F" and paste it into the appropriate cell in another tab.

    3. Special Features

      1. To locate the Special Feature code you will need to enter, first locate the feature in the Special Feature Message column. For this example, we will use "Ergonomic Item."

        2. The Special Feature Message column.

      2. The Type column specifies if your feature is a Special Feature or an Environmental Feature.

        3. The Special Feature Type column.

      3. Directly to the left of the Special Feature Message column is the Special Feature Code column. You will see that the code for an "Ergonomic Item" is "BD."

        4. After finding your feature, locate its corresponding code

      4. You will then copy "BD" and paste it into the appropriate cell in another tab.

  2. The Field Definitions tab provides a list of each field included in the various screens of the Formatted Product Tool process and a corresponding definition.

    The Field Definitions tab.

    1. For example, if you were required to enter your product's Unit of Issue on another tab, you would first locate it under the Field column of this tab.

      2. Locate the term for which you need a definition.

    2. Next, you would look directly to the right to find that term's definition under the Field Definition column.

      3. After locating your term, find the corresponding definition.

    3. This will help you determine what you need to enter into each field for your particular product or accessory.

  3. The Reference tab provides you with the all the possible options you can enter for fields including but not limited to warranty periods, delivery codes, and discount types.

    The Reference tab.

    1. Option Code:

      1. The Option Code defines how the option relates to the base product. There are four potential values, which are defined as follows:

        • I - option is included as a feature of product, and cannot be removed

        • S - option can be substituted for another option

        • A - option can be added to the base product; it is not required to be selected

        • O - none can be selected

      2. Determine your Option Code.

    2. Product Type:

      1. This field informs you that you can enter with "Product" or "Accessory" in any column with this name.

      3. Determine your Product Type.

    3. Discount Type:

      1. This column indicates that there are two types of discounts: Volume/Quantity Discounts and Dollar Discounts.

      4. Determine your Discount Type.

    4. Warranty Period:

      1. There are two columns pertaining to warranty periods: Manufacturer Warranty Period and Extended Warranty Period. Both of these columns include the options you can enter for either of these fields.

      5. Options for the Manufacturer and Extended Warranty Periods.

    5. Delivery Lead Time Code

      1. This column helps you identify the method in which your company determines delivery lead time. The choices are as follows:

        • AF - for time delivered after receipt of order

        • AE - for time shipped after receipt

      6. Determine your Delivery Lead Time Code.

    6. Delivery FOB:

      1. Free On Board (FOB) defines delivery options. Use these columns to help you determine the codes for the type of delivery you offer within the Continental US first, and then in the non-contiguous US territories. The choices are as follows:

        • O - Origin - shipping is paid by the seller

        • D - Destination - shipping is paid by the buyer

        • ND - No Delivery - delivery is not offered to this destination

        2. Locate the codes that correspond with your Delivery FOB offerings.

page.name: template-pricing-tab
page.title: Pricing Tab
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/download_pricing_tab_lesson

book Instructions

On this tab, you will enter your general pricing information along with descriptions of your item(s). You must complete each required field as marked with an asterisk (*). Remember to save your work frequently to avoid losing your data.

  1. Entering your pricing data.

    1. Cells marked with an asterisk (*) are required. We suggest you fill out one row in the Excel spreadsheet, save your information, and then attempt to upload for validation purposes. If your document returns errors, it will be much easier to fix them as you go along rather than in a group at the end.

  2. Enter your SIN.

    1. Double click on the first cell and enter your SIN.

      2. Enter your SIN.

  3. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

    1. The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) is the number created by, and assigned to a product by the manufacturer of said product. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way. (Example: HSC0424PP)

      2. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

  4. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

    1. The Manufacturer Name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. (Examples: Honeywell, Samsung, or DeWalt)

      2. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

  5. Enter the Product Type.

    1. For this field, type either "Product" or "Accessory" depending on your offering.

      2. Enter the Product Type.

  6. Enter the Product/Accessory Name.

    1. Enter the name of the product or accessory you are offering.

      2. Enter the Product/Accessory Name.

  7. Enter the UPC/ISBN/GTIN 14/EAN 8/EAN 13.

    1. For this field, enter numbers only between 8 and 14 digits. Most products submitted for sale on a Federal Supply Schedule will follow the UPC-A 12-character format. (Example: 8-92685-00100-3)

      2. Enter the UPC/ISBN/GTIN 14/EAN 8/EAN 13.

  8. Enter the Vendor's Product/Accessory Description.

    1. Enter a brief description of your product or accessory (1,000 character maximum).

      2. Enter the description.

  9. Locate the Unit of Issue Code.

    1. For this field, locate the Code Lookup tab at the bottom of the Excel spreadsheet and refer to the Unit of Issue Name column.

      2. Locate the Unit of Issue Code in its column.

  10. Enter the Unit of Issue.

    1. The Unit of Issue describes in what format, quantity, or packaging a product will be sold. The most common unit of issue is "each," but other examples include, but are not limited to: "box," "pack," or "dozen."

      2. Helpful Hint: For a product like a monitor, which is usually sold individually, the unit of issue would most likely be "each" and the quantity per unit would be "1." However, with products like markers that are sold more than one in a package, the unit of issue would be "package" and the quantity per unit would be the number of markers in the package (i.e. 8).

      Enter the Unit of Issue.

  11. Enter the Quantity Per Unit.

    1. The quantity per unit is the number of individual units that are contained in a unit of issue.

    Enter the Quantity Per Unit.

  12. Enter the Quantity of Product/Unit.

    1. If applicable, enter the quantity of product per unit in the text box provided.

      2. Enter the Quantity of Product Per Unit.

  13. Enter the Vendor Part Number.

    1. If applicable, enter the Vendor Part Number in the text box.

      2. Enter the Vendor Part Number.

  14. Enter the Commercial List Price.

    1. Enter the offer price into the Commercial List Price text box using numbers only, with a maximum of 17 digits before the decimal and 4 digits after the decimal (e.g. $45,000.00).

      2. Enter the Commercial List Price.

  15. Enter the Name of your Best Priced Customer.

    1. The Best Priced Customer is the name of a customer or category of customers (commercial or government entity) in which your company offers the absolute best price, independent of terms, conditions, discounts, and/or concessions.

      2. Enter the best priced customer's name.

  16. Enter the Price Offered to Best Priced Customer.

    1. Enter the price you offered to the customer from the previous tab into the Price Offered to Best Priced Customer column.

      2. Enter the price offered.

  17. Enter the Discount Offered to Best Priced Customer.

    1. Enter the discount you gave the customer in column M in a percentage format into the Discount Offered to Best Priced Customer column. You can enter up to 8 digits before the decimal point, and 4 digits after it. Do not enter any letters or special characters.

      2. Enter the discount offered.

  18. Save your file.

    1. Save the Excel spreadsheet to your computer.

      2. Save your file.

page.name: non-pricing-tab
page.title: Non-Pricing Tab
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/download_reference_tabs_lesson

book Instructions

This tab is where you will enter information not related to pricing, including the production point, warranty information, and product dimensions.

  1. Enter your SIN.

    2. Enter your SIN.

  2. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

    1. The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) is the number assigned to a product by the manufacturer of said product. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way. (Example: HSC0424PP)

    3. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

  3. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

    1. The Manufacturer Name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. (Examples: Honeywell, Samsung, or DeWalt).

    4. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

  4. Enter the Production Point.

    1. The Production Point is the country in which the product is manufactured. Refer to the Code Lookup tab to locate the code for your item's Production Point.

    5. Enter the Production Point.

  5. If applicable, enter the Production Point 2.

    1. If your product is manufactured in more than one country, use the Production Point 2 field to indicate the additional country. Refer to the Code Lookup tab to locate the code for your item's Production Point 2.

    6. Enter the Production Point 2.

  6. If applicable, enter your Manufacturer Warranty - Warranty Period.

    1. The Manufacturer Warranty - Warranty Period is the unit of time that the manufacturer's warranty is expressed in. Select the appropriate option. Available values are "day," "week," "month," "year," or "lifetime."

    7. Enter your Manufacturer Warranty - Warranty Period.

  7. If applicable, enter the Manufacturer Warranty - Number of Warranty Periods.

    1. The Manufacturer Warranty - Number of Warranty Periods indicates the period that the warranty covers. If your warranty is a one-year warranty, and you selected "year" for "warranty period," you would put a "1" in this field. If you selected a warranty period of "lifetime," you would put "0" in this field.

    8. Enter the Manufacturer Warranty - Number of Warranty Periods.

  8. If applicable, enter the Manufacturer Warranty - Description.

    1. The Manufacturer Warranty - Description is a description of the coverage provided by the manufacturer's warranty. If the terms are spelled out in another place, then provide the location of those terms.

    9. Enter the Manufacturer Warranty - Description.

  9. If applicable, enter the Extended Warranty - Warranty Period.

    1. The Extended Warranty Period is the unit of time that the warranty is expressed in. Select the appropriate option. Available values are "day," "week," "month," "year," or "lifetime."

    10. Enter the Extended Warranty - Warranty Period.

  10. If applicable, enter the Extended Warranty - Number of Warranty Periods.

    1. The Extended Warranty - Number of Warranty Periods is the period that the extended warranty covers. If your extended warranty is a one-year warranty, and you selected "year" for "warranty period," you would put a "1" in this field. If you selected a warranty period of "lifetime," you would put "0" in this field.

    11. Enter the number of warranty periods for the extended warranty.

  11. If applicable, enter the Extended Warranty - Description.

    1. The Extended Warranty - Description is a description of the coverage provided by the manufacturer's extended warranty. If the terms are spelled out in another place, then provide the location of those terms.

    12. Enter the Extended Warranty - Description.

  12. If applicable, enter the Product Length - Unit Number.

    1. The Product Length - Unit of measure is the standard unit that was used to measure the product's length. This field is for defining the numerical value only. The unit of measure will be defined in a separate field.

    13. Enter the Product Length - Unit Number.

  13. If applicable, enter the Product Length - Unit of Measure.

    1. The Product Length - Unit of Measure is the standard unit that was used to measure the number of units. Examples of units of measure are: "feet," "inches," or "meters."

    14. Enter the Product Length - Unit of Measure.

  14. If applicable, enter the Product Width - Unit Number.

    1. The Product Width - Unit of Measure is the standard unit that was used to measure the width of the product. This field is for defining the numerical value only. The unit of measure will be defined in a separate field.

    15. Enter the Product Width - Unit Number.

  15. If applicable, enter the Product Width - Unit of Measure.

    1. The Product Width - Unit of Measure is the standard unit that was used to measure the number of units. Examples of units of measure are: "feet," "inches," or "meters."

    16. Enter the Product Width - Unit of Measure.

  16. If applicable, enter the Product Height - Unit Number.

    1. The Product Height is the standard unit that was used to measure the product's height. This field is for defining the numerical value only. The unit of measure will be defined in a separate field.

    17. Enter the Product Height - Unit Number.

  17. If applicable, enter the Product Height - Unit of Measure.

    1. The Product Height - Unit of Measure is the standard unit that was used to measure the number of units. Examples of units of measure are: "feet," "inches," or "meters."

    18. Enter the Product Height - Unit of Measure.

  18. If applicable, enter the Product Specific Web Site.

    1. The Product Specific Website is used to provide a URL for a page with data specific to this product. For example, if you maintain your own online catalog, you may opt to provide a link to this page.

    19. Enter the Product Specific Web Site.

  19. If applicable, enter the Standard Pack.

    1. The Standard Pack is the unit of measure you consistently sell items in packages of a specific size and type. This field is optional. Standard packs always consist of multiple quantities of the same item. Standard packs do not contain multiple items. For example: 12.

    20. Enter the Standard Pack.

  20. If applicable, enter the Delivery (Lead) Time Days.

    1. For example, if you plan to select "AE" for your Delivery (Lead) Time Code and enter "5" into the Delivery (Lead) Time Days field, then the expectation is that the product will ship (leave your company) 5 days after you receive the order.

    21. Enter the Delivery (Lead) Time Days.

  21. Enter the Delivery (Lead) Time Code.

    1. Use this field to identify the method in which your company determines delivery lead time. The choices are as follows:

      • AF - time delivered after receipt of order

      • AE - time shipped after receipt

    22. Enter the Delivery (Lead) Time Code.

  22. If applicable enter the Federal Supply Classification/Product Service Code (FSC/PSC), the United Nations Standard Products and Services Code (UNSPSC), and/or the National Stock Number (NSN). These are numerical indicator codes that further define an item.

    1. These are numerical indicator codes that further defines an item.

    23. Enter the FSC/PSC, UNSPSC, and/or NSN.

  23. If applicable, enter the Default Color.

    24. Enter the Default Color.

  24. Click the Save button to ensure your work is not lost.

    25. Save your work.

page.name: special-charges-tab
page.title: Special Charges Tab
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/download_special_charges_lesson

book Instructions

This tab corresponds to the selections you made in the Wizard Management: Special Charges section. Be sure to only enter information for fields that match your earlier choices.

  1. Enter your SIN.

    2. Enter your SIN.

  2. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

    1. The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) is the number created by, and assigned to a product by the manufacturer of said product. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way. (Example: HSC0424PP)

    3. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

  3. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

    1. The Manufacturer Name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. (Examples: Honeywell, Samsung, or DeWalt)

    4. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

  4. Refer back to the Special Charges section of Wizard Management that you completed earlier. It is imperative that you only fill in information in your template for the charges you selected previously.

    5. Only complete Special Charges from those you selected previously in eOffer.

  5. Locate the column that corresponds to your earlier selection(s). For instructional purposes, we will complete the columns for "Expediting Premium."

  6. Complete the Charges field.

    1. For this field, enter a number that represents the dollar amount your company will charge.

    7. For this example, we will fill out the Charges field.

  7. Complete the Per field.

    1. For this field, you will need the Unit of Issue Code to which your charge applies. Refer to the Code Lookup tab for a complete list of Units of Issue and their corresponding codes. You may have to scroll down to locate your code.

      2. Use the Code Lookup sheet as a reference for Special Charges.

    2. Enter your code.

      3. Enter your code.

  8. Enter a description explaining the special charge.

    9. Enter a description explaining the special charge.

  9. Click the Save button to ensure your data is not lost.

    10. Click Save.

  10. Repeats steps 2-8 for any additional items.

page.name: special-features-tab
page.title: Special Features Tab
page.body:
This tab corresponds to the selections you made in the Special Features section of Wizard Management. Be sure to only enter information for fields that match your earlier choices.

  1. Enter your SIN.

    2. Enter your SIN.

  2. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

    1. The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) is the number created by and assigned to a product by the manufacturer. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way.

    3. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

  3. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

    1. The Manufacturer Name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. (Examples: Honeywell, Samsung, or DeWalt)

    4. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

  4. Recall the Special Features selections you made as part of Wizard Management earlier in the process. It is imperative that you only enter data for the selections you made previously. The other columns can remain blank.

    5. Only enter information in columns that correspond to features you previously selected in eOffer.

  5. Scroll to locate the Environmental Features that apply to your item. For instructional purposes, we will complete the column pertaining to "Green Seal Item."

    6. For the purpose of this lesson, we will complete the Green Seal Item field.

  6. You will need to locate the code that corresponds with your Special Feature.

    1. On the Code Lookup tab, use the Special Feature Message column to locate your special feature, then find the row to the left to determine the appropriate code.

    7. Use the Code Lookup page as a reference for what to enter within the spreadsheet.

  7. Copy and paste that code into the appropriate cell.

    8. Copy and paste the correct code into the corresponding cell.

  8. Next, scroll to find Special Features that correspond with your earlier selection.

    9. Continue to fill out other applicable Special Features.

  9. Repeat steps 6-7 with this field.

    10. Repeat the previous steps to fill out each special feature.

  10. When you are finished, click the save button to ensure your data is not lost.

    11. Click Save.

page.name: template-delivery-tab
page.title: Delivery Tab
page.body:
This is where you will enter your Delivery information. You must complete each required field as marked with an asterisk (*).

  1. Enter your SIN.

    2. Enter your SIN.

  2. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

    1. The Manufacturer Part Number (MPN) is the number created by, and assigned to a product by the manufacturer of said product. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way. (Example: HSC0424PP)

    3. Enter the Manufacturer Part Number.

  3. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

    1. The Manufacturer Name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. (Examples: Honeywell, Samsung, or DeWalt)

    4. Enter the Manufacturer Name.

  4. Enter Delivery - FOB Continental US.

    1. Free On Board (FOB) defines delivery options. Use this field to select the type of delivery you offer within the Continental US. The choices are as follows:

      • O - Origin - shipping is paid by the seller

      • D - Destination - shipping is paid by the buyer

    5. Enter the Delivery FOB.

  5. Enter Delivery FOB - Alaska.

    1. Free On Board (FOB) defines delivery options. Use this field to select the type of delivery you offer to Alaska. The choices are as follows:

      • O - Origin - shipping is paid by the seller

      • D - Destination - shipping is paid by the buyer

      • ND - Delivery is not offered to this destination

    6. Enter Delivery FOB - Alaska.

  6. Enter Delivery FOB - Hawaii.

    1. Free On Board (FOB) defines delivery options. Use this field to select the type of delivery you offer to Hawaii. The choices are as follows:

      • O - Origin - shipping is paid by the seller

      • D - Destination - shipping is paid by the buyer

      • ND - Delivery is not offered to this destination

    7. Enter the Delivery FOB - Hawaii.

  7. Enter the Delivery FOB - Puerto Rico.

    1. Free On Board (FOB) defines delivery options. Use this field to select the type of delivery you offer to Puerto Rico. The choices are as follows:

      • O - Origin - shipping is paid by the seller

      • D - Destination - shipping is paid by the buyer

      • ND - Delivery is not offered to this destination

    8. Enter the Delivery FOB - Puerto Rico.

  8. Enter the Shipping Unit Weight.
