  3. Click on the Choose File button and navigate to the file that matches exactly with the name of the photo you entered previously.

    4. Choose your file.

  4. Once your file has been chosen, click the Upload File button.

    5. Click the Upload File button.

  5. You will see your photo added to the table at the bottom of the screen.

    6. Your photo has been added to the table.

  6. Repeat steps 3-5 for any additional photos you wish you add.

  7. Click the Go To Capture Pricing button to complete this section.

    8. Click the Go To Capture Pricing button.

page.name: generate-offer-analysis-report
page.title: Generate Offer Analysis Report
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/generate_offer_analysis_lesson

book Instructions

Completing this section will trigger the process to generate the Offer Analysis Report. Generation of the document can take up to 30 minutes depending on the number of the products. You must complete this section before generating your pricing document.

  1. To enable this button, ensure all of the following validations are met:

    • at least one product/accessory, with all the required details, is associated with each SIN

    • data is captured for all required fields

    • data is entered as per specified format (where applicable)

  2. From the Capture and Generate Pricing Screen, click on the Generate Offer Analysis Report button.

    3. Click on the Generate Offer Analysis Report button.

  3. If the status of your report reads "Generation of Offer Analysis Report: In Progress," it is still generating and not yet ready for the next step.

    4. Note the status of your report.

  4. It may take up to 30 minutes for your status to change. To refresh the status of your report, click the Check Status button.

    5. Click the Check Status button.

  5. When the system has finished running your report, you will notice that the status has changed to "Complete."

    6. Note the "Complete" status.

  6. Click the Go To Offer Analysis Report link.

    7. Helpful Hint: You must click this link and fix any errors before moving on. If you do not complete this step first, you will not receive an accurate final pricing document.

    Click on the Go To Offer Analysis Report link.

  7. You will be taken to a screen that includes two tabs:

    • Line Items: Required Action

    • Line Items: Require No Action

    You will need to correct all errors under the Line Items: Required Action tab.

    8. View the section(s) that require action.

  8. Click on the button in the Action column. As an example, we will be working with errors in the Pricing section.

    9. View the section(s) that require action.

  9. To continue our example, this table indicates that the prices we entered are too high and need to be adjusted to fall within the target prices.

    10. A look at the Pricing items that require action.

  10. By clicking in the cell under New Offer Price, you can change the price to fall within the Target Price (Incl. IFF) that has been provided.

    11. Adjusting pricing to fall within the Target Prices.

  11. Now that we have adjusted the prices, click the Save Changes button.

    12. Save your changes.

  12. Click OK on the Standard Response Confirmation pop-up message.

    13. Click OK.

  13. You will notice all cells are clear under the Line Items: Required Action tab.

    14. When the Line Items: Required Action field is blank, you have corrected all errors.

  14. Click the Save Standard Responses button.

    15. Click Save Standard Responses.

  15. Click OK on the Standard Response Confirmation pop-up message.

    16. Click OK.

  16. Back on the Capture and Generate Pricing screen, your status should read "Generation of Offer Analysis report is Complete."

    17. Note the "Complete" status.

page.name: generate-pricing-document
page.title: Generate Pricing Document
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/generate_pricing_lesson

book Instructions

This section will trigger the process to generate your Pricing Document. Generation can take up to 30 minutes depending on the number of products added.

  1. To enable this button, you must first have achieved a "Complete" status on the Offer Analysis Report section.

    2. Your Offer Analysis Report must be complete before moving on to this section.

  2. Click the Generate Pricing Document button.

    3. Click the Generate Pricing Document button.

  3. Your screen will change to read "Generation of Pricing Document is In Progress."

    4. Note the "In Progress" status.

  4. Generation of the document can take up to 30 minutes, but you can check the status at any time by clicking the Check Status button. You will need to refresh your screen by clicking this button until the status is Complete.

    5. Click the Refresh Status button until your status reads "Complete."

  5. Once your status reads "Complete," click the View Final Pricing Document link.

    6. Click the View Final Pricing Document link.

  6. A document will open that contains all of the information you have entered throughout the process.

    7. Open the Final Pricing Document.

  7. You may save a copy of this document for your records, or simply move on to Entering Your Standard Responses.

    8. Save a copy for your records.

page.name: entering-your-standard-responses
page.title: Entering Your Standard Responses
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_standard_responses.mp4

There are five specific questions that you must respond to in this section, each of which relate to various acts, programs, or administrative issues relating to your GSA Schedule Contract Offering. Though there is some information available on screen, in the text below we identify some of the important elements of each of the questions to which you are required to respond.

Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program

Under the Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program, state and local government entities may purchase a variety of Products and Services from Contracts Awarded under GSA Federal Supply Schedules to facilitate recovery from a major disaster, terrorism, or nuclear, biological, chemical, or radiological attack.

State and local government entities may use GSA Schedule Contracts to purchase Products and Services in advance of a major disaster declared by the president, as well as in the aftermath of an emergency event. State and local government entities are responsible for ensuring that the Products or Services purchased are to be used to facilitate recovery.

By selecting Yes to participation in the Disaster Recovery Purchasing Program, your Company becomes eligible to provide Products or Services in the event of a disaster.

Exceptions to Terms and Conditions

The "Exceptions To Terms and Conditions" question asks whether or not you agree to all the standard terms and conditions described in the Solicitation package. While reading through the Solicitation documents, you should have noted whether there was anything you did not agree with. If you found a particular clause or term that was not to your liking, you should open a new document, identify the term, and provide your rationale as to why you are taking an exception to the term.

Exceptions to ORCA Certs and Reps

The "Orca Certs and Reps" question confirms that your information in ORCA is up to date. If there have been any changes to your Company information (such as a change in company size, NAICS, etc.), you should answer 'No' and provide information to GSA as to why you have done so.

Participation in ARRA

The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 provided GSA with several billion dollars for investments in Federal buildings, procurement of more energy-efficient motor vehicles, and additional funding for the GSA Inspector General to provide oversight to the GSA Programs and Projects funded by the Recovery Act. With its implementation, new clauses have been added to the Contract. You must choose whether or not you agree to these clauses.

Participation in E-Verify

The Employment Eligibility Verification or "E-Verify" is an Internet-based system that allows an employer-using information reported on an employee's Form I-9 (Employment Eligibility Verification)-to determine the eligibility of that employee to work in the United States. This new system allows you to certify online whether or not all of your employees are eligible to work in the U.S.

  1. Respond to all the listed questions and click Save Response.

    2. Enter your standard responses.

  2. When the Information Saved message appears, click Continue.

    3. Click 'Continue' at the Information Saved message.

  3. You will continue on to the Responding to Solicitation Clauses section.

page.name: responding-to-solicitation-clauses-overview
page.title: Responding to Solicitation Clauses Overview
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_solicitation_clauses_overview.mp4

In this section, responses to Solicitation Clauses need to be completed. These clauses are listed in each of the four (4) required templates: Basic Information, Commercial Sales Practice, Point of Contacts, and Ordering Information. Starting with the Basic Information template, you will need to click on the Respond link in the Actions column for each section to complete this process.

page.name: basic-information
page.title: Basic Information
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_solicitation_clauses_basic_info.mp4

Click the Respond link corresponding to the Basic Information template.

  1. Click on the Respond link in the Actions column for each clause.

    2. Helpful Hint: This screen will look different depending on the solicitation under which you are preparing your offer. Your screen will not look identical to the screenshot posted here.

  2. Complete each action item as listed.

  3. The "DELIVERY PRICES (MAY 1991)" Clause will be used as an example.

    • Click on the Respond link in the Actions column for the specific clause to which you are responding.

      • Click the Repond link corresponding to the Clause you want to complete.

    • Check the boxes that apply.

    • Click on the Preview button.

    • Your information will be generated into a PDF document. Once you save your information in eOffer, that PDF will be available for modification at a later date if your contract is awarded.

      • Check the appropriate boxes and click Preview.

    • Click on the Save button to return to the Basic Information field's home screen.

      • After your PDF is displayed, click Save.

page.name: commercial-sales-practice
page.title: Commercial Sales Practice
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_solicitation_clauses_csp.mp4

  1. In the Commercial Sales Practice row, click on the Respond link in the Actions column.

    2. Click on the Respond link corresponding to the Commercial Sales Practice template.

  2. For Question 1a, enter a dollar figure that reflects the the total sales of the product or service during the previous 12-month period or during the last fiscal year.

  3. For Question 1b, designate the 12-month period for which you are providing the dollar figure. If you feel that the dollar figure is not an appropriate measure for sales, provide your own measure of the sales of the item(s) in the free-form box.

  4. Use the free-form box in section Question 2b to add any additional notes or comments that may be helpful to your CO.

    5. Enter your total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all options, for each SIN.

  5. For Question 2a, the total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all options, will be pre-populated for each SIN. This information is pulled from the Goods/Services > Add SIN(s) screen. To change this information, return to this screen and click on the Edit link in the Actions column.

    6. The total projected annual sales to the Government under the contract for each SIN offered will be pre-populated.

  6. Use the free-form box in section Question 2b to add any additional notes or comments that may be helpful to your CO.

  7. Question 3 asks you if, based on your discount policies, your prices are as good or better than prices offered to any other customer acquiring the same items, regardless of quantity or terms and conditions. Click Yes or No accordingly.

    8. Identify whether the concessions you offer the Government are equal to or better than the best price offered to customers.

  8. The next step is to identity the level at which you want to specify the discount or concession policy. This can be done at an Offer/Contract level or specified down to the individual SIN. In the case of line item EAS Schedules, those can be specified down to the line item level.

    9. Select the level at which you want to specify the discount/concession policy.

  9. Question 4a allows you to specify the details of your discount policy, and the options here change depending on whether you have selected a discount/concession policy based on the Offer/Contract level or the SIN level. First, though, you must work through the initial information on this screen. Upon saving, you will be able to enter further details.

    10. Fill out this first page and save it before adding details to your Discount Policy.

  10. In Question 4b, answer whether or not any deviations from your written policies or standard CSP disclosed in 4a ever resulted in better discounts (lower prices) or concessions than indicated.

    1. If you answer Yes, include the following:

      • discussion on any situations that lead to deviations from standard practice

      • an explanation of how often they occur

      • the controls you employ to assure the integrity of your pricing

        • Helpful Hint: Examples of typical deviations may include, but are not limited to: one-time goodwill discounts to charity organizations or to compensate an otherwise disgruntled customer; a limited sale of obsolete or damaged goods; the sale of sample goods to a new customer; or the sale of prototype goods for testing purposes.

    2. If deviations from your written policies or standard commercial sales practices disclosed in the chart on the Commercial Sales Practices Format are so significant and/or frequent that the Contracting Officer cannot establish whether the price(s) offered is fair and reasonable, then you may be asked to provide additional information. The Contracting Officer may ask for information to demonstrate that you have made substantial sales of the item(s) in the commercial market consistent with the information reflected on the chart on the Commercial Sales Practice Format, a description of the conditions surrounding those sales deviations, or other information that may be necessary in order for the Contracting Officer to determine whether your offered price(s) is fair and reasonable. In cases where additional information is requested, the Contracting Officer will target the request in order to limit the submission of data needed to establish the reasonableness of the offered price.

  11. When you have completed all fields, click Save.

    12. Answer the question on deviations.

  12. The screen will update whether you have chosen to specify your discount/concession policy at the Offer/Contract level or at the SIN level.

    13. Choose the option that is the basis for your proposed GSA price.

    1. If you chose the Offer/Contract level, you can specify your discount in terms of a discount or a markup/build-out.

    2. A discount is, plainly, a discount from the original price

    3. A markup is based on the markup over cost (e.g. a 5% markup over the manufacturer's catalog price). This is common for dealer/resellers. Imagine your company is a dealer/reseller of widgets. The manufacturer catalog price that you pay for the widgets is $10 per widget. The price you are offering GSA is a 5% markup on the price you pay the manufacturer, or $10.50.

    4. A build-out is derived from a buildup of individual costs. Your proposed GSA price is derived by totaling the individual cost elements that it takes to produce your product or service, and then adding an amount for profit. Profit, or fee, is usually expressed as a percentage of the cost elements. Your GSA proposed price will typically be a reduced profit or fee applied to the cost elements (e.g. labor + general & administrative + overhead + 5% profit = proposed GSA labor rate).

  13. Click Update Basis.

    14. Select your basis and click Update Basis.

  14. You will be taken to a screen to select the basis for your policy with more detailed descriptions of your options. Choose your basis and click Save.

  15. If your discount policy is at the SIN level, you will be able to define the basis for each SIN discount policy. You will see your SINs listed below. Click Update Basis to continue.

    16. Click Update Basis.

  16. For each SIN, you will be able to choose whether the basis for the CSP is Discount or Markup/Build-out. Make your choices and click Save.

    17. Select your basis and click Save.

  17. You will be taken back to the updated CSP creation screen. You will now be able to add your discount policy. If you wish to change the level of your specificity on your discount policy, you may click Update Level, otherwise click Add Discount Policy to enter your discount/concession information.

    18. Click Add Discount Policy.

  18. You will be taken to the Discount Policy / Concession Terms interface to enter your policy details. Note that if you selected a SIN or Line Item Policy, you will be able to specify which ones to which the discount applies; these fields will be absent for an Offer/Contract level discount policy.

    19. Discount Policy / Concession Terms Page

  19. Use the following information to complete each column of the chart:

    • Customer: Customer is the customer (e.g, Company XYZ) or category of customer (e.g., dealers, distributors, State, County, City and Local Governments, etc.) who receive the terms being disclosed.

    • Discount: Provide any basic discount offered this customer. A basic discount is any discount offered without regard for quantity (e.g., for a quantity of one). If you do not offer any basic discounts, insert "NONE".

    • Quantity/Volume: Provide any quantity or volume discounts offered this customer. For example, a discount of 10% is offered when 20+ units are purchased, OR a discount of 10% is offered when the net order exceeds $20,000.00. This discount is exclusive of any Basic Discount offered.

    • FOB Terms: Provide the FOB Terms (Freight Terms) offered this customer. For example, FOB Origin (Plant), FOB Origin Freight Prepaid and Allowed, or FOB Destination.

    • Concessions: Provide any other terms or conditions, not previously listed, which are offered to this category of customer. For example, any prompt-payment terms, aggregate discount terms, enhanced or additional services offered, etc.

    • More detailed instructions and information can also be found by clicking the link directly above question 4 on the CSP-1.

    The link about question 4a has a wealth of information on your CSP.

  20. When you are finished, click Save to return to the main CSP page.

  21. You will now see the discount policy information added to the Discount Policy table, where you can Edit or Delete the policy as needed.

    22. Your discount policy has been added.

  22. If applicable, you may also add multiple policies by clicking Add Discount Policy.

    23. You can add multiple discount policies.

  23. When you are satisfied with your Commercial Sales Practice, click Save under the textbox provided in 4b.

    24. When you are satisfied with your CSP, click Save.

page.name: point-of-contacts-information
page.title: Point of Contacts Information
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_solicitation_clauses_poc.mp4

  1. Click on the Respond link in the Actions column.

    2. Click the 'Respond' link corresponding to the Point of Contacts Information template.

  2. Click on the Select Point of Contact Information drop-down menu and select the type of contact you are entering. When you have made a selection, click Add Point of Contact Details.

    3. Helpful Hint: A good place to start is with the Contact for Contract Administration (Domestic) entry, as this is mandatory, assuming you are a U.S.-based company. If you are incorporated overseas, click the (Overseas) selection.

    Select a category in the Point of Contact Information drop-down, then click Add Point of Contract Details.

  3. Click on the Add Point of Contact Details button in the Action column.

    4. Once Point of Contact information has been entered, click on the Add Point of Contact Details button.

  4. Fill in each text box with the relevant contact information and click the Add Point of Contact button.

    5. Fill in each text box with your POC's information.

  5. Once you have completed the form for each point of contact, click the Back to Solicitation Clauses button.

    6. Once your new Point of Contact appears on the Points of Contact table, return to the Solicitation Clauses screen.

page.name: ordering-information
page.title: Ordering Information
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/solicitation-clauses/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_solicitation_clauses_ordering.mp4

  1. Click on the Respond link in the Actions column.

    2. Click the Respond link corresponding to the Ordering Information template.

  2. Click on the Select Ordering Information drop-down menu.

  3. Select Ordering Receipt Information and click the Add Ordering Information Details button.

    4. Choose Ordering Receipt Information from the drop-down and add the details.

  4. Fill in all mandatory fields as indicated by an asterisk (*).

    5. Helpful Hint: When selecting facsimile transmission, you do not need to enter the contact information in the area below. Alternatively, to receive Orders via fax, you can elect to establish an electronic means for receipt of Orders by selecting the Computer to Computer Electronic Data Interchange option. In order to receive Orders via EDI, you will need to set up an interface with the government.

    In addition, you do not need to set up the interface prior to Contract Award, but you do need to provide the contact information for the person who will be responsible for setting up the EDI with the government. This person will be contacted by GSA after Contract Award to establish the interface.

  5. When the form is complete, click Add Ordering Information.

    6. Complete each required text box field and add your ordering information.

  6. Next, click on the Select Ordering Information drop-down menu again, but this time select Remittance Address and click the Add Ordering Information Details button.

    7. Choose Remittance Address from the drop-down menu and add your details.

  7. Fill in all mandatory fields as indicated by an asterisk, (*), then click Add Ordering Information.

    8. Helpful Hint: The Remittance Address Information could be your primary corporate address or, in the cases of larger businesses, where the sector or department responsible for Order processing and payment remittance is located.

    Complete each required text box field and add your ordering information.

  8. You will be taken back to the original Ordering Information screen, but this time you will see your ordering information displayed. Click the Back to Solicitation Clauses button.

    9. When information has been added for both fields, return to the Solicitation Clauses screen to continue.

  9. The status for the Ordering Information section will change to "Complete", at which point all necessary information in the Solicitation Clauses section will be complete. Click Save and Continue.

    10. You have entered all of the required information.

  10. At the Information Saved message, click Continue.

    11. Click Continue to move on to the next section.

  11. Depending on your previous responses to the Standard Responses, you may need to continue on to enter a Subcontracting Plan, to Justify Your Clause Exceptions, or Upload Supporting Documents.

page.name: responding-to-solicitation-provisions
page.title: Responding to Solicitation Provisions
page.body:
As a part of the eOffer, vendors have to submit a technical proposal, covering topics such as corporate experience, past performance, and quality control. Starting in May 2015, each solicitation in eOffer will include a new section, titled "solicitations provisions". In this section, offerors will address provisions specific to each solicitation, and provide written detail about their corporate experience, past performance, and quality control.

Requirements of each section of the provisions are listed with the corresponding text entry boxes. This ensures consistency and completeness. You must respond to all provisions listed in the table, before you may submit your offer.

  1. The Solicitation Provisions page will display a list of provisions necessary for you to complete. The list of solicitation provisions may vary depending to which solicitation you are submitting an offer as well as your provided SINs. Begin by clicking Respond next to the first solicitation provision, in this case, Corporate Experience.

    2. Key Concept: The list of Solicitation Provisions will vary depending on the chosen schedule. It is possible your list looks different than the example below.

    Click Respond next to the solicitation provision

  2. The Corporate Experience section allows you to give an overview of your business and how it relates to the services and products you wish to provide to the Federal government. Fill out each section in sufficient detail, bearing in mind the 10,000 character limit. When you are finished click Save and Continue.

    3. Caution: The maximum permissible limit for the entire page across each section is 10,000 characters or about two pages.

    Complete each section for Corporate Experience

  3. The Past Performance Section requires you to provide your Past Performance Evaluation from ORI. Note that the evaluation must have been issued no more than one year from the date of proposal submission. Provide the Past Performance Evaluation date, and attach the supporting documentation. Address any negative feedback within the textbox. Click Save and Continue when you have finished.

    4. Caution: The Past performance Evaluation must be from within one year of the date of proposal submission

    Provide your Past Performance

  4. Provide your Quality Control process and procedures. Regardless of the variety of products and services your business provides, submit a single narrative across the various sections.

    5. Provide your Quality Control process and procedures

  5. As previously stated, the various solicitation provisions may vary from solicitation to solicitation. If you are providing products, you may see the Trade Agreements Act (TAA) Compliance provision. You are required to ensure TAA compliance. Read the provided prompt and acknowledge the statement to be true. When you are finished click Save and Continue.

    6. Acknowledge that you are responsible for ensuring TAA compliance

  6. When all sections of the solicitation provisions are complete, click Save and Continue.

    7. When you are finished each section, click Save and Continue

page.name: justifying-your-clause-exceptions
page.title: Justifying Your Clause Exceptions
page.body:
If you recall from the Standard Response section, you were asked whether or not you were taking any exceptions to the standard Terms and Conditions. If you did not take any exceptions in the previous Standard Responses section, skip the next section, Clause Exceptions, and move on to the Upload Documents. However, If you answered 'Yes' to Exceptions to Terms and Conditions, follow the steps below:

  1. You will be presented with a list of contract clauses for taking exception(s). Select the Regulation(s) for which you are taking exceptions by clicking the check box. Then click the Select Regulations button.

    2. Select the Clause against which you wish to take an exception, then click 'Select Regulation.'

    Helpful Hint: If you need to view the clause you can click on the Clause Number which is given as a link. The clause body will open up in a separate window as a PDF.

  2. On the next screen you will see an Exceptions Text box as well as the Excerpt From Clause box. Notice that now you have an Exceptions section in your eOffer menu on the left. Review the Instructions. To view the clause click on the Clause link.

    3. Click the Clause number link when you are ready to select your text

  3. The clause body will open up as a pdf file. Highlight and copy (Ctrl+C) the text for which the exception is being taken (as demonstrated below).

    4. A PDF will open up, select and copy the text against which you wish to take exception.

  4. Click in the Excerpt From Clause box and press press (Ctrl+V). The text will get copied. Click the Ready To Edit button. A pop up will display. Click OK.

    5. Paste your text into the Excerpt from Clause box and click Ready to Edit

  5. The text you have selected will be replicated in the Exception Text box.

    6. The text will appear below, ready for editing

  6. Make the changes in the Exception Text box and click Save Exception Text. The application will move on to the next clause with which you had taken exception. Repeat the process.

    7. Make your edits then click Save Exception Text

    Key Concept: If exception is being taken to only one Regulation the Save And Continue button will be seen instead of the Save Exception Text.

  7. If you click the Back to List button the list of contract clauses will be displayed. You will notice that your Exception clauses will be at the top of the list now with the option to Edit or Delete. Click Save and Continue, when you are done with all the exceptions.

    8. The finished Exception will display a green check. Click Save and Continue to move onto the Upload Documents screen.

page.name: subcontracting-plan
page.title: Subcontracting Plan
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/subcontracting-plan/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_subk_overview.mp4

In the Standard Response section, you were required to answer questions with regard to a Subcontracting Plan. The decision tree will determine if your business is required to submit a Subcontracting Plan as a result of that input.

Helpful Hint: If your input in the Subcontracting Plan decision tree under Standard Responses resulted in no required Subcontracting plan, skip this section and move on to Upload Documents. However, if you qualify for a plan, this section will need to be completed.

This is an example in which a Subcontracting Plan is not required.

This is an example in which a Subcontracting Plan is required

A Subcontracting Plan is required on a Contract under certain situations. Generally, the Federal Acquisition Regulations (FAR) require a Subcontracting Plan from a Contractor classified as "Other than Small Business," when the actual Sales of a Contract exceed the $650,000 threshold or $1,500,000 for construction.

  1. You will be presented with options for the creation or upload of your Subcontracting Plan. If you already have a Subcontracting Plan, choose from the first set of options that will allow you to upload either a Master, or Commercial Plan. If you do not have a Subcontracting Plan, the second option will guide you through the steps to create one. Select either Individual Plan or Commercial Plan then click Save Plan Type.

    2. Select the Subcontracting Plan type.

    Key Concept:Commercial Plans cover a vendor's fiscal year and apply to the entire production of commercial items sold by either the entire Company or a portion there of. They apply both to commercial and government business, and affect all government Contracts in that applicable year. Individual Plans cover an entire Contract period and apply to one Contract specifically.

  2. After selecting which Subcontracting Plan you wish to create, you will see an overview screen with each subsection of the Subcontracting Plan and its status. For the purpose of this walk-through, we will follow an Individual Plan. To begin, click 'Respond' on the line corresponding to the first section, Identification Data.

    3. Click the Respond button on the line corresponding to the Identification Plan section.

  3. Enter a detailed description of your Supplies/Services in the textbox. Next enter your Place of Performance, and then the Estimated Contract Value covering the Base Period and all of the Option Periods. Before you click 'Next,' press the Save button.

    4. Enter a Description and Estimated Contract Values.

  4. The Goals section is where you state the percent of the Contract value that you intend to designate for the various Subcontracting categories. Begin by clicking 'Add' under the action column.

    5. Click the Add link under your Base period goals.

  5. You will need to enter the Total Dollars to be Subcontracted, which will be the sum of the Subcontracting Goals for both Large Businesses and All Small Businesses. When filling out the Large Business goals, you will find the system will automatically complete either the percentage or dollar amount, depending on which you choose to fill out. This will help you along the way ensure you are doing the proper math and that everything adds up.

    6. Fill in your Base Period Subcontracting Goals.

  6. Next, fill in the Small Business Type goals. These goals should be considered independently, not as values that equal your goals for All Small Businesses. As there may be instances in which Subcontractors qualify for multiple designations, each of the Small Business types could add up beyond the total of the All Small Businesses goals. When you are finished, click 'Save,' then click 'Next' to move on.

    7. Fill in your Small Business Type Subcontracting Goals before continuing.

  7. You will see the Subcontracting values reflected in the Goals chart. If you wish to fill any subsequent Option period with the same goals as the Base period, click the Copy link. Otherwise skip to step 15 below.

    8. If applicable, you can copy your goals from the Base period to fill in subsequent Option periods.

  8. The Base period's values will be copied to the Option periods you select. When you have made your selections click 'Copy,' then click 'Next.'

    9. If applicable, select the periods to which you want to copy your Base Period Small Business Type Goals.

  9. The Goals chart will now have matching values wherever you have chosen to replicate the Base period's values. You also have the ability to Edit or Delete each Option period.

    10. You will now be able to see replicated goals reflected in the Goals table

  10. To select which Supplies or Services are to be Subcontracted, click the Add button.

    11. Click 'Add' to select which Supplies or Services are to be Subcontracted.

  11. Identify the Supply or Service to be Subcontracted and select which type of Subcontractor will be leveraged. When you have finished, click 'Save' before continuing to add other entries as needed. When you are finished, click 'Next.'

    12. Enter the Supply or Services and their applicable designations.

  12. The List of Supplies or Services will now display your entries and corresponding eligible Subcontracting types with the ability to Edit or Delete each entry.

    13. The Services or Supplies are now displayed in the Services/Supplies table.

  13. Next-using evidence from historical data, experience, or research-explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals in Section C.

    14. Explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals.

  14. Enter a detailed description on how your Company plans to identify potential partners to meet your Subcontracting goals in Section D.

    15. Enter a detailed description of how your Company plans to identify potential partners to meet your Subcontracting goals

  15. Finally, in Section E, state whether indirect costs have been included in the Subcontracting goals. If they have been accounted for, explain the methodology used to calculate these costs in the textbox below. When you are finished click 'Save,' then click 'Next.'

    16. State whether indirect costs have been included in the Subcontracting goals. Account for the calculation, then click 'Save' to move on.

  16. You will be taken to the Program Administrator screen. You cannot add this information directly into the Subcontracting Plan utility, rather it is added to the Solicitation Clauses section. The Subcontracting Plan generates the associated points of contact there. Click the Solicitation Clauses link on the left-side navigation menu.

    17. Click the Solicitation Clauses link on the left-side navigation menu to enter your Admin Point of Contact.

  17. On the Solicitation Clauses screen, you will notice the addition of the Point of Contacts Information entry. Click the Respond link in the Actions column.

    18. Click the Respond link for Point of Contact Information.

  18. Select 'Contact for Subcontracting Plan' from the dropdown menu and click 'Add Point of Contact Details.'

    19. Select the contact for the SubContracting Plan from the dropdown menu.

  19. Fill out the Administrator's contact information.

    20. Enter the contact information for the Administrator.

    Helpful Hint: While not required, it is a good idea to also add an alternate contact for your Subcontracting Plan.

  20. After adding your Subcontracting Plan Point of Contact and an alternate Point of Contact,click 'SubContracting Plan' in the left-side navigation menu in order to return to the Subcontracting Plan screen.

    21. Click the SubContracting Plan link on the left-side navigation menu.

  21. You will notice that Point of Contact details are now displayed.

    22. You will notice Point of Contact details are now displayed.

  22. Next, you will need to identify the duties of the the Subcontracting Plan Administrator. One through five are required by the FAR. Select the applicable functions, meant to ensure effective implementation of the Subcontracting Plan. Identify any additional measures in the textbox at the end of the list. When you are finished click 'Save,' then click 'Next' to continue.

    23. Select the applicable Subcontracting Plan Administrator duties.

  23. The Equitable Opportunity section summarizes your businesses efforts to ensure Equitable Opportunity and Competition for small business, including outreach efforts and internal Programs designed for purchasing personnel. Check all applicable boxes and describe any additional efforts in the textbox provided. Click 'Save' before clicking 'Next' to move on.

    24. Select the applicable Equitable Opportunities your business plans to pursue

  24. The Clause Inclusion and Flow Down section contains the assurance that all Subcontracts in excess of $650,000 ($1,500,000 for construction) adopt a plan which Offers further Subcontracting opportunities. You must first agree to this by checking the box, then click 'Save' before clicking 'Next' to move on.

    25. Check the box agreeing to Assurances of Clause Inclusion and Flow Down

  25. The Reporting and Cooperation section contains assurances required by FAR that all Contractors will submit various forms of Reports, including a timetable for Individual Subcontract Reports. All Contractors must agree to these conditions. Confirm your agreement by clicking the check box, then click 'Save' before clicking 'Next.'

    26. Check the box agreeing to Reporting and Cooperation measures.

  26. In the Record Keeping section, confirm your intent to maintain Records throughout the course of the Subcontracting Plan. Provide evidence of your ability to comply with Record Keeping standards using the text box following number 7 of this section. Click 'Save and Continue' when you are finished.

    27. Agree to Record Keeping standards, provide evidence of your ability, then click 'Save and Continue' when you are finished.

  27. In the Statutory Requirements section, confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click 'Save and Continue.'

    28. Confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  28. The final section is the Good Faith Effort. You must give a detailed outline of the steps your Company plans to take to achieve your Subcontracting goals in good faith. When you have finished click 'Save.' Save.

    29. Briefly describe the actions your Company will take to meet its Subcontracting goals in Good Faith.

  29. Once you have finished the Good Faith Effort section, you will see a message saying your progress has been saved successfully. In order to continue, use the navigation on the left to proceed to the Upload Documents section.

    30. Choose 'Upload Documents' from the Navigation menu on the left.

page.name: uploading-your-documents
page.title: Uploading Your Documents
page.body:
The Upload Documents screen allows you to provide additional supporting documentation to the offer. This is the final step prior to submission. The mandatory documents required for all eOffers are indicated with an asterisk (*). If an additional document types need to be uploaded, please use the Other (optional-offeror defined) category.

This is the Upload Documents screen

Helpful Hint: The list of mandatory documents may change depending upon the solicitation you are responding to. Each solicitation has some requirements that may be unique to it.

By the time you get to this screen, you should have already completed all of the required documents and have them ready to upload. If you have not, however, you can view the solicitation document by clicking the "View PDF" link to get more information on any of the necessary documents that you still need to complete.

  1. Click the Upload link against the category for which you need to attach the document.

  2. Click Choose File to locate documents to be attached. Select the document you want to upload.

    3. Click Choose File and select your document

  3. Enter the name of the document in the What is the document name? field. Note that this does not need to be the actual file name. Just give it a name that is relevant and meaningful. Click on Upload This Document to add the document. This will take you back to the Upload Documents screen.

    4. Enter a meaningful name and click Upload This Document

  4. As you upload documents, you will notice that the Status of the document will change to Uploaded and in the Actions column there will be an option to Delete the uploaded document. The document can also be reviewed by clicking the file name which will appear as a hyperlink.

  5. Repeat the process to upload all the required documents as well as any optional ones. Once all the required documents (as well as any additional documentation you want to provide) have been added, click Save and Continue.

  6. You will see an Information Saved message, click Continue to review your eOffer one time prior to submission on the Submit eOffer screen.

page.name: submitting-your-eoffer
page.title: Submitting Your eOffer
page.body:
1. Once you have completed all sections of your eOffer, you will have arrived to the submitting your eOffer screen. It will ask you if you are ready to submit. Select Yes. You will still have time to review your eOffer one last time.

    2. Click Yes to confirm you are ready to review your eOffer one final time before submission.

  2. Review the documents attached earlier in the eOffer process by clicking on the Review link. Be sure to review the accuracy of each of your documents.

    3. Review each attachment prior to submission.

  3. Read the Disclaimer carefully and select Yes for both statements (if in agreement) and click Continue.

    4. Read the Disclaimer thoroughly, select your answers, and click Continue.

  4. The system will verify the name and email ID of the Negotiators. This information is displayed on the Negotiator Digital Certificate Details page. Ensure the information is correct. If the information is not correct, it will be indicated under the Status. Go back to the Adding Your Negotiators section and make corrections and click Submit Offer to continue. If the information is correct upon review, click Submit Offer.

    5. Read the Disclaimer thoroughly, select your answers, and click Continue.

  5. You will now see a Success Message that your submission has been received.

    6. The Success Message

  6. Exit the application or go to the inbox by clicking the appropriate link.

  7. The status of the submitted eOffer will change to Offer Received on the "My eOffers" homepage under "Submitted eOffer."

    8. Helpful Hint: After the submission of an eOffer, it is still possible to Edit or Withdraw the eOffer.

    The eOffer will appear under Submitted eOffers.

  8. Once the eOffer is received, it will be assigned to a Contract Officer (CO) or a Contract Specialist (CS) and a New Offer Welcome Letter will be generated once the processing begins. An example of such a letter is shown below.

    9. This image shows a New Welcome Offer Letter e-mail example

  9. Under Submitted eOffers the status of the eOffer will change to "Contract Specialist Reviewing" as shown below.

    10. This image shows the Submitted eOffers screen, the Contract Specialist Reviewing Status is highlighted.

  10. While the CO is performing his or her initial review, the vendor will be prevented from making any changes. This will be indicated by the "locked" icon. When the offer is editable, an unlock icon will be displayed.

    11. The eOffer locked/unlocked legend

  11. Upon award of the contract, the Contract Specialist will create a contract package to be approved and signed by the vendor. For detailed steps, refer to the Signature Process section.

page.name: post-submission-of-your-eoffer-overview
page.title: Post-Submission of Your eOffer Overview
page.body: eOffer allows you to perform a number of functions after the submission of your Offer. The following instructions will outline these functions and provide greater clarification in terms of post-submission offer management.

page.name: responding-to-requests-for-clarification-due-to-an-exception
page.title: Responding to Requests for Clarification Due to an Exception
page.body:
After the eOffer has been submitted, the CO/CS may have questions regarding a clause exception. In this case, a request for clarification email will be sent to the vendor.

An email requesting clarification

Open eOffer, Log in, and access the My eOffers window. The eOffer in need of explanation will be displayed under Submitted eOffers with the Status of Provide Clarification.

  1. Click on the Provide Clarification link.

    Click the Provide Clarification link.

    The "Exception Contract Clauses submitted by vendor" page will be displayed. (Note: the history of Request for Clarifications can be viewed by clicking the view link.)

  2. In the Action column, click Respond.

    Click the Respond link.

    The exception status page is displayed showing the Submitted Exception Text with comments from CO/CS.

  3. The Revised Exception Text is pre-populated box. Enter the Exception Clarification.

    4. Helpful Hint: The history of the negotiations can be viewed by clicking the link at the bottom of the screen

  4. Click Save to Draft.

    5. Revising your Exception Text

  5. The "Status" of the exception will change to Completed. At this point, you also have the option to edit your response.

  6. If you are satisfied with your answer Click Submit Response.

    7. Submitting your Response

  7. The success message will be displayed. The CO/CS will then choose to approve, ask for further clarification, or reject the exception.

page.name: rejection-of-an-exception-by-a-co-cs
page.title: Rejection of an Exception by a CO/CS
page.body:
The CO/CS may reject an exception. This is typically done in more extreme circumstances as a CO/CS typically would prefer the vendor to have the ability to provide clarification as to what was being described in their exception. However, from time to time, it does happen.

In cases such as these, you will receive an email notification as shown below, but you cannot respond to the rejection through the eOffer/eMod system.

This is an example of a Rejection email

The offer will still be under evaluation as indicated by the status on the "My eOffers" page. The only options available to you are to either Edit or Withdraw the offer.

The options to Edit or Withdraw your offer

page.name: editing-an-eoffer-after-submission
page.title: Editing an eOffer After Submission
page.body:
If a submitted eOffer requires some changes for whatever reason, you have the ability to do so via the Edit Offer functionality. This can be done while the eOffer is under review by the Contract Specialist.

  1. From the MY eOFFERS window, click on the Edit Offer button. This will take you to the Corporate Information page.

    2. Editing an eOffer after submission

  2. Using the menu on the left under Prepare your eOffer, you may go to any section of the offer and make changes.

    3. Navigating the already-submitted eOffer

  3. Once done, the offer will have to be re-submitted by clicking on Submit eOffer in the menu. You should see a submission success message.

page.name: rejection-of-an-eoffer-by-a-co-cs
page.title: Rejection of an eOffer by a CO/CS
page.body:
1. If the Contract Specialist rejects the eOffer, an email stating that the offer has been rejected will be generated as shown below:

    2. An example of a rejection email by a CO/CS

  2. If the vendor wishes to resubmit the offer for that particular solicitation, the eOffer will need to be recreated as a new offer. See the next chapter, Re-Submitting an eOffer After Rejection for instructions.

page.name: re-submitting-an-eoffer-after-rejection
page.title: Re-Submitting an eOffer After Rejection
page.body:
To resubmit an eOffer that was rejected by the Contract Specialist, sign in to Contract Offers (eOffers).

  1. Once the system is accessed, the My eOffers page will be displayed.

  2. The rejected offer can be located under Submitted eOffers with the status of "Rejected".

    3. The Rejected Status in Submitted eOffers

  3. To re-submit the rejected offer, locate the correct solicitation number (same as the rejected solicitation number) under Select Solicitation and click Submit Online.

    4. Resubmit an eOffer by selecting the same solicitation

  4. The System offers an option to import the data from the "Rejected" eOffer. Click Yes on the Confirm Import screen if data is to be pre-populated.

    5. Confirming your import

  5. Click Continue.

  6. Ensure the information is accurate and complete in all sections listed in the Prepare Your Offer menu and submit the eOffer.

page.name: withdrawing-your-eoffer
page.title: Withdrawing Your eOffer
page.body:
An eOffer may be withdrawn for any reason, at any time, prior to the CO signing the contract package.

  1. To withdraw an offer go to the My eOffers page.

  2. Find the offer to withdraw under Submitted eOffers and click Withdraw Offer in the Actions column.

    3. Withdrawing an eOffer

  3. Click Yes on the Confirm Withdraw screen.

  4. The status of the eOffer will change to "Withdrawn".

    5. The Withdrawn status

  5. The CO/CS will receive an email notifying the offer was withdrawn.

    6. Caution: If you are inactive in the system for more than 30 minutes the eOffer session will time out. Click on eOffer Home and log back in to resume your session.

page.name: signature-process-overview
page.title: Signature Process Overview
page.body: The Signature process applies to both eOffer and eMod, yet remains largely similar regardless of the module in which it is performed. That said, note that in these instructions the Signature Process are illustrated using the eOffer module.

page.name: reviewing-and-esigning-the-contract-package
page.title: Reviewing and eSigning the Contract Package
page.body:
Upon award of the contract, the Contract Specialist will create a contract package to be approved and signed by the vendor. A vendor Notification for Proposal eSignature will be sent in the form of an email with instructions to review and sign the proposal.

  1. Click the URL in the email to begin the review and signature process.

    2. Users will receive an email notification to eSign the Contract Package.

  2. After the login process is complete, the My eOFFERS page will be displayed.

    3. Key Concept: If your offer contains set aside and non set aside SINS, you will see two packages (one for each type of SIN).

  3. The package created by the Contracting Specialist will be displayed under Signed eOffers. You may View Offer, View Package or Sign Package. In case of an eMod, it would be under the Signed Modifications section.

    4. Users may view the offer, sign the package, or view the package.

  4. To view the offer click the View Offer button shown above and you will be able to review all your responses as well as all the documents.

  5. You may review each document by clicking the Review link.

  6. To simply review the contract package (Form 1449), click View Package.

    7. Review the various responses in the package.

  7. On the "View Package" page click Continue.

  8. On the next screen click the link Review and Accept.

    9. Click Review and Accept.

  9. This will allow you to view the Standard Form 1449 as shown below. In case of eMod, it will be the Form SF 30.

    10. This is the SF 1449.

  10. Use the Back button at the bottom of the form, not your browser's button, to get to the previous screen OR hit the Exit button to navigate back to the My eOffers page.

  11. To move on with signing the package, click Sign Package. The Sign Contract screen will be displayed.

  12. Click the Review link against each document that needs to be reviewed. After the documents have been reviewed, click the checkbox to confirm and then click Continue.

    13. Review the contract documents, confirm your reviewal, and click continue

    Caution: This is consent for the use of electronic records and signatures tool for this offer only, not an acceptance of the offer. You still have the option to reject the offer.

    Accept the eSignature

  13. To streamline the e-Signature process, the SF-1449 form is the only document that will be listed for review and acceptance (in case of eMods it will the SF 30 form). Click on the Review and Accept link to move forward to the form. Note that at this time you still have the option to reject by clicking the Reject eOffer button.

    14. You must review the SF 1449, click Review and Accept

  14. Review the SF-1449 Form and click Accept in the bottom right corner.

    15. Accept the SF1449

  15. Click Sign eOffer. Again you still have the option to reject the offer.

    16. You may sign or reject the eOffer

  16. Click Confirm to the question of "Are you ready to sign this eOffer?"

  17. The success message will display.

    18. Notification that the package has been successfully eSigned.

  18. The status of the contract package will change to Awaiting CO esign or it might indicate Processing Vendor esign. The CO will receive notification that the contract is ready for signature.

    19. The status will change to either Awaiting CO esign or Processing Vendor esign

  19. Once the CO has signed the package, the Status will change to Signed by Contracting Officer. A notification email is sent to the Vendor (as shown below) stating the award letter will be mailed subsequently. Also right next to the View Package you will see the Download Package button.

    20. Once the CO/CS has signed the package, you will be able to View and Download the package

    Caution: In instances when there are multiple offers, where there exists both set-aside and non-set-aside contracts, the download package button will not be displayed until the contract and CO have signed BOTH the set-aside and non-set-aside contract packages

page.name: rejecting-the-contract-package
page.title: Rejecting the Contract Package
page.body:
You may find that there is a discrepancy in the contract package and you do not wish to sign the eOffer. In these cases, you can reject the contract package outright.

  1. After the documents have been reviewed, the package may be rejected by clicking the Reject eOffer.

    2. To reject the package, click the Reject button

The CO will receive an email notifying the contract package has been rejected. The CO will make the necessary corrections and recreate the contract package. A new email notification will be generated to the vendor indicating the offer is ready for Review and Signature.

page.name: downloading-the-package-windows-version
page.title: Downloading the Package (Windows Version)
page.body:
The eOffer signed by the CO will appear under the Signed eOffers section on the My eOffers page. At this point the Offer Package may be downloaded.

  1. Click Download Package against the eOffer which has been Signed by the Contracting Officer.

    2. Click Download Package

  2. On the next screen click Continue. Please read the instructions carefully, particularly about having Adobe Reader installed on your system. Click on the link Download my documents (Windows version).

    3. Click the Download Link

  3. On the pop-up click Run. The Silanis installer will be initiated and it will install the ApproveIt eSignature Verifier.

    4. Run the Silanis download

  4. Click Next.

    5. Read the instructions and click Next

  5. Read the next screen and click Next.

    6. Read the instructions and click Next

  6. Choose your installation location and click Next.

    7. Choose your installation location and click Next

  7. Continue through the rest of the installation

    8. Continue through the rest of the installation

  8. The next screen will show you the installation progress.

  9. After the installation you will see an Approved Documents short-cut on your desktop

    10. An Approved Documents shortcut will be place don your desktop

  10. Double click on this short-cut and you will see the PDF version of the Form 1449 with all the contract details.

    11. Things to Remember: The above steps describe the process for downloading the contract package using Windows. If you are not on a Windows O/S, the steps are very similar, but may require you to Save files (as opposed to running the application) and use an "Unzip" tool to get to the actual files.

page.name: preparing-an-electronic-contract-modification-emod
page.title: Preparing an Electronic Contract Modification (eMod)
page.body:
eMod is a web-based application that allows vendors to submit their Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) contract modification requests electronically (eMods). eMod uses the digital authentication technology in order to ensure the integrity of data, and provides electronic signature capability. A digital certificate is required in order to use eMod. See the section on Digital Certificates for more details.

Using eMod, a vendor can submit multiple mods within a single transaction. Different type(s) of mods and their associated subtypes can be selected. Another feature of eMod allows GSA contracting personnel to "split" mods. For example, a Contracting Officer (CO) has the ability to perform a split if one of the mods can be done quickly, but the other mod action may require more time to complete.

Rather than waiting for both mods to be completed at the same time, splitting the mod expedites the process.

Key Concept: While the following discussion outlines the process of a vendor- submitted contract modification, a GSA Contract Officer (CO) or Contract Specialist (CS) is able to issue unilateral mods that do not require vendor confirmation.

page.name: getting-started-with-emod
page.title: Getting Started with eMod
page.body:
To access the eMod application, a valid Digital Certificate must be present on your computer.

  1. Go to the GSA eOffer/eMod homepage.

  2. Click on the Sign In button located in the Contract Modifications (eMods) section.

    3. The eOffer/eMod Landing Page

  3. On the pop-up window, choose the correct certificate (if there is more than one) and click OK.

    4. Confirm your digital certificate.

  4. Select the appropriate DUNS number using the drop-down or manually enter it in the text box and click Submit.

    5. Select your DUNS.

  5. On the next screen, select the contract number from the dropdown that needs to be modified, and click the Select Contract button.

    6. Select your contract

  6. At this time, the My Modifications page will be visible where you can create new Mods, work on saved ones, or edit submitted ones.

    7. Caution: If you are not an assigned Negotiator for a contract, you will be asked to contact the Point of Contact (POC) of your company.

    This image shows the My Modifications screen.

page.name: creating-an-emod
page.title: Creating an eMod
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/getting-started-with-emod/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_creating_emod.mp4

Creating an eMod is the bread and butter of the eMod system. In the following steps, we will show you how to navigate the system to modify your existing MAS contract. In fact, we will show you how to submit a mod for each of the modification Primary Types and Subtypes.

From the "My Modifications" home page, you can see all of the saved, submitted, and signed modifications. You can create a new eMod (as described below) or edit an existing one. Note that if you are opting to edit an existing modification, a new "Lock" functionality has been introduced that may not allow you to work on a submission. If a modification has been locked, there will be a "closed lock" icon next to it. If a user wishes to edit a submitted modification, they can request to unlock the mod by clicking the "Edit Mod" button. If the mod is already unlocked, a user can edit the modification just by clicking the "Edit Mod" button.

  1. Click the drop-down box under New Modifications, select the appropriate contract number, and click the Select Contract button.

    2. Select your contract from the dropdown menu then click 'Select Contract.'

  2. The next screen will list the nine primary modification types and the subtypes within.

  3. Select the modification subtype(s) that need to be created and click Submit Online.

    4. Key Concept: It is important to note that eMod will not allow you to submit multiple modification requests for the same type of mod action. For example, if you have already submitted a modification for a Website Address Change, the system will prompt you to view the existing mod rather than allow you to create a new one.

    Check the desired mod(s) and click 'Submit Online.'

    Key Concept: As you can see, there are a plethora of different modification types available to you. For demonstration purposes, we will guide you through the necessary steps to complete each modification type. You may note above that we are electing to begin with the Additions mod types.

  4. The Corporate Information page will be displayed next. Review all the information and click Save and Continue. If something needs to be corrected, click the Sign out and Correct Errors in CCR button.

    5. Verify that your Corporate Information is correct and click 'Save and Continue.'

  5. Once you click Save and Continue, a message saying "Information Saved" will be displayed.

    6. Click Continue on the 'Information Saved' screen.

    Helpful Hint: The menu on the left shows the section(s) competed and allows you to jump to any section.

  6. To learn about each individual modtype, browse the Modtypes.

page.name: modtypes-overview
page.title: Modtypes Overview
page.body:
There are nine primary modtypes, each of which includes several subtypes pertaining to various processes and procedures relevant to the modification process. Each is detailed in this section.

A look at the table outlining the nine modtypes and their corresponding subtypes.

page.name: additions-modifications-overview
page.title: Additions Modifications Overview
page.body:
Additions modifications focus on any adjustments to a vendor's product offerings and core services, as keeping those up to date ensures that customers are making investment decisions based on current information regarding a company's capabilities.

The Additions Modifications.

page.name: add-labor-category-and-or-service-offerings
page.title: Add Labor Category and/or Service Offerings
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/additions-modifications/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_add_labor_service.mp4

As your business evolves, you may want to add additional offerings to provide to your customers; this is the facility to add those.

  1. Log into the eMod system and select your contract.

    • For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.

  2. Select Add Labor Category and/or Service Offerings from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the 'Add Labor Category' subtype and click 'Submit Online.'

  3. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. You will be asked as to whether or not you will need to update your Commercial Sales Practice (CSP-1) with information about your new labor category or service offering. (For more information on updating your CSP, read the Update/Revise Commercial Sales Practice section.)

    6. Update your Commercial Sales Practice.

  6. Enter detailed information about your new Labor Category and/or Service in the textbox and click Save Description.

    The goal here is to make the review of the CO as easy as possible. Some information you can provide may include:

    • the SINs against which the labor category and/or Service Offering is applicable

    • a description of the labor category and/or Service Offering

    • the associated duties, responsibilities, educational requirements, and experience required of a person assigned to this new labor category and/or Service Offering.

    Helpful Hint: Note that Service Offerings differ from Labor Categories in that they are primarily based on a fixed price versus a labor hour pricing arrangement. Be clear about the modification in your description.

    Enter detailed information about your new Labor Category and/or Service in the textbox.

  7. On the Information Saved message, click Continue.

    8. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  8. On the Upload Documents screen, you will be able to attach supporting documentation for your eMod.

  9. Click on the Upload link under the Action column for each type.

  10. Note: You are required to upload documents for every type marked with an asterisk. If you have additional documents that are not required, upload them on this screen under the corresponding Type column.

    11. Click on 'Upload Documents' for each required Type.

  11. Click on the Browse button to locate the file you want to upload.

  12. Give the document a name, then click Upload This Document.

    13. Upload your document.

  13. Repeat these steps for each Type that requires supporting documentation.

  14. When you are finished, the Status column will read "Uploaded."

  15. To add additional documentation, click on the Upload Additional link under the Action column.

  16. Click Save and Continue.

    17. Click 'Save and Continue' to move onto the next screen.

  17. On the Information Saved screen, click Continue.

    18. On the Information Saved screen, click 'Continue.'

  18. On the Confirmation screen, click Yes.

    19. On the Information Saved screen, click 'Continue.'

page.name: add-product-s
page.title: Add Product(s)
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/additions-modifications/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_add_product.mp4

Adding products to your business profile is a natural part of growth and progress. Find out how to do that here.

Step 1
Initial Steps

Initial Steps

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Add Product(s) from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Add Product(s) modification subtype and click Submit Online.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. You will be asked as to whether or not you will need to update your Commercial Sales Practice (CSP-1) with information about your new labor category or service offering. (For more information on updating your CSP, read the Update/Revise Commercial Sales Practice section.)

    6. Determine if you need to update your CSP.

  6. Select the SIN(s) you wish to modify and click on the right-facing arrow.

    Select the SIN(s) for modification.

  7. You will see your SIN(s) listed in the Selected SIN(s) box to the right.

    8. Your SIN(s) will appear to the right.

  8. Enter a detailed description of your modification request in the provided text box. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

    9. Enter your details and save your work.

  9. On the Information Saved message, click Continue.

    10. Click Continue

  10. Click on Capture Pricing on the left hand navigational menu.

    11. Go to the Capture Pricing section.

page.name: administrative-modification-overview
page.title: Administrative Modification Overview
page.body:
Administrative modifications deal primarily with changes to your company information such as points of contact, your company e-mail address or telephone and fax numbers. Current contact information is the first step in securing desired business connections.

The Administrative Modification subtypes

Helpful Hint: There are 9 subtypes available within the Administrative modifications. However the "Subcontracting" subtype is only visible if the Contract requires a subcontracting plan.

Key Concept: If a vendor has performed a company address or name change in SAM, (s)he will be required to execute a contract modification for such a change in eMod. Upon accessing the eMod system, the vendor will be notified of the name/address change via a pop-up message. The user will be required to confirm the new name/address and will be prompted to apply the new address to any other schedule contracts that his or her company may hold.

page.name: address-change
page.title: Address Change
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/administrative-modifications/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_address_change.mp4

Keeping your contact information up to date is imperative to maintaining the health of your business.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Address Change from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Address Change subtype and click Submit Online

  3. Verify your corporate information, click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen

  5. A new address may impact your DUNS, to begin with you will be asked if you would like the replace the existing DUNS on this contract. For the purpose of this demonstration we are going to respond Yes, and take you through the process.

    6. Would you like to replace your DUNS?

  6. When you select Yes, two new fields will appear, prompting you to enter the new DUNS number, and if applicable, the Plus 4 number. Enter your DUNs and click Save and Continue.

    7. Enter your new DUNs and click Save and Continue

  7. You will be asked to confirm that the information appearing with your new DUNS number is correct. Review the information to ensure it is correct and click Save and Continue.

    8. Caution: If any information on the Corporate Information screen is not correct, you will need to make corrections in SAM. To access SAM, go to www.sam.gov, or look for the SAM link under the "Before You Begin" section on the eOffer/eMod homepage. After the corrections are made, the eOffer/eMod system will update in approximately 24 hours.

    Enter your new DUNs and click Save and Continue

  8. Enter your new address information into the screen and click Save and Continue.

    9. Enter your address change into the textbox

  9. On the information saved message click Continue.

    10. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen

  10. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    11. Upload and Submit your modification

  11. When you are finished you will see a success message.

    12. Your mod has been submitted successfully

  12. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: authorized-negotiator
page.title: Authorized Negotiator
page.body:
video
video_library_page/example_library/emod/administrative-modifications/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Femod_authorized_negotiator.mp4
video
video_library_page/example_library/eoffer/authorized-negotiators/https:%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Felucid-demo-videos%2Feoffer_authorized_negotiators.mp4

Depending on their assigned role, Authorized Negotiators can either sign binding Contract documents, or remain limited to simply preparing eMods. It is important for these roles to be clearly distinguished at all times.

Key Concept: An Authorized Negotiator is the term used for an individual prior to Contract Award. After an Award has been made, that same person will now be referred to as a Contract Administrator. This is really a distinction without a difference insofar as the system is concerned, however.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your Contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select 'Authorized Negotiator' from the list of modification Subtypes and click 'Submit Online.'

    3. Select the Authorized Negotiator Subtype and click 'Submit Online.'

  3. Verify your corporate information, then click 'Save and Continue.'

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click 'Continue' at the "Information Saved" message.

    5. Click 'Continue' at the "Information Saved" message.

  5. On the Administrative screen, under Your Negotiator(s) Details table, note the links under the Action column. Here, you can Edit details for a Negotiator, or Delete that Negotiator. To add a new Negotiator, click the Add New Negotiator button below the table.

    6. Manage your current Authorized Negotiators, or add a new one.

  6. When adding a new Negotiator, complete the fields for his or her Name, Title, Phone, and Email. You must also assign this new Negotiator a role, designating whether he or she is Authorized to Sign or Not Authorized to Sign. Click 'Add this Negotiator' when you are have completed the necessary information.

    7. Key Concept: Remember that there are basically two types of Negotiators;those who are authorized to sign documents binding a Company to a Contract with GSA, and those who are only allowed to prepare an eMod.

    Add details for your new Negotiators, then click 'Add this Negotiator.'

  7. You will now see your new Negotiator within the Your Negotiator(s) Details table. Click the Save & Continue button.

    8. Your new Negotiator is now added to the table.

  8. At the "Information Saved" message, click 'Continue.'

    9. Click 'Continue' at the "Information Saved" message.

  9. You will be required to upload documents in support of this modification. (For more information, read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod. Afterward, you will have a chance to perform a final review of your eMod.

    10. Upload and submit your modification documents.

  10. Successful modification submission will be acknowledged by a "Success" message.

    11. Notification of a successfully submitted modification.

  11. You will now see your Modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For information about the processes after submitting your eMod, read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.
