page.name: create-manage-clause-exceptions
page.title: Create/Manage Clause Exceptions
page.body:
GSA currently lists dozens of contract clauses outlining guidelines pertaining to everything from equipment purchases to privacy act notifications. Should your company not be able to meet one of these requirements, an exception must be put forth for approval by the CO.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Create/Manage Clause Exceptions from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Create/Manage Clause Exceptions subtype and click Submit Online.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue.

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Select the clause(s) for taking exception and click Select Regulation.

    6. Select the clause(s) for taking exception.

  6. On the Exception Text screen, you will notice there is a link to the selected regulation at the top of the screen. There are also two text boxes on the screen. To begin, you need to select the text from the regulation against which you wish to take exception. Click the Regulation Link to open a PDF.

    7. Click the regulation link.

  7. This will open a PDF with the regulation text. Highlight the text against which you wish to take exception and press Control-C to copy it. Then close or minimize the PDF.

    8. Copy the clause text against which you wish to take exception.

  8. Back on the Exception Text screen, select the Excerpt from Clause text box and paste the previously copied text here by pressing Control-V. When you are satisfied, click Ready to Edit. This will populate the Exception Text textbox below.

    9. Paste the Exception Text into the Excerpt from Clause textbox and click 'Ready to Edit.'

  9. You can now make your changes in the Exception Text textbox. After you are satisfied with your edits and you have only taken one exception, click Save and Continue. If you have taken exception to multiple clauses, click Save Exception Text and then Continue to Next and the previous texts with each clause.

    10. Make your changes to the Exception Text.

  10. On the Information Saved message, click Continue.

    11. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

  11. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    12. Upload and Submit your modification.

  12. When you are finished, you will see a success message.

    13. Your mod has been submitted successfully.

  13. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: cooperative-purchasing
page.title: Cooperative Purchasing
page.body:
The Cooperative Purchasing Program allows state, local, and tribal governments to acquire services through a specific set of GSA schedule contracts.

  1. Log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod section.)

  2. Select 'Cooperative Purchasing' from the list of Modification subtypes and click 'Submit Online.'

    3. Select the Cooperative Purchasing subtype and click 'Submit Online.'

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Update your response to the Cooperative Purchasing question. Use the selector buttons to indicate Yes or No, then click the Save and Continue button.

    6. Change your response to the Cooperative Purchasing question.

  6. When prompted by the Information Saved message, click the Continue button.

    7. When prompted, click 'Continue.'

  7. You will be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterward, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    8. Upload your Modification documents.

  8. When you are finished, you will see a Success message. Click the My eMods link to return to the My Modifications page.

    9. Notification that your eMod has been successfully submitted.

  9. You will notice your Modification appears under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes that follow submission of your eMod, read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: disaster-recovery
page.title: Disaster Recovery
page.body:
The Disaster Recovery Program allows your company to receive orders involving funds marked by recovery efforts in the wake of federally designated disasters.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod section.)

  2. Select Disaster Recovery from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Disaster Recovery subtype and click 'Submit Online.'

  3. Verify your corporate information, then click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Update your response to the Disaster Recovery question. By participating, your company becomes eligible to receive orders made by state and local government entities to facilitate recovery from a major disaster or terrorist attack. Use the selector buttons to indicate Yes or No, then click the Save and Continue button.

    6. Change your response to the Disaster Recovery question.

  6. When prompted by the Information Saved message, click the Continue button.

    7. When prompted, click 'Continue.'

  7. You will be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterward, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    8. Upload your Modification documents.

  8. When you are finished, you will see a Success message. Click the My eMods link to return to the My Modifications page.

    9. Notification that your eMod has been successfully submitted.

  9. You will notice your Modification appears under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes that follow submission of your eMod, read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: e-verify
page.title: E-Verify
page.body:
The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services' E-Verify system is used to verify employees' eligibility to legally work in the United States.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select E-Verify from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the E-Verify subtype and click Submit Online.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue.

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen

  5. Update your response to the E-Verify, the Internet-based system that allows an employer, using information reported on an employee's I-9 Form, to determine the eligibility of that employee to work in the United States. Federal contractors are required to use this system to certify whether their employees are eligible to work in the US. Select Yes or Not Applicable, then click Save and Continue

    6. Enter a detailed description of your Service Descriptive modification

  6. On the information saved message click Continue.

    7. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen

  7. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    8. Upload and Submit your modification.

  8. When you are finished, you will see a success message.

    9. Your mod has been submitted successfully.

  9. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: re-representation-of-non-novated-merger-acquisition
page.title: Re-representation of Non-Novated Merger/Acquisition
page.body:
A non-novated merger or acquisition implies that all terms and conditions of your GSA contract are not being transferred to the firm being acquired by or merged with your company. In the event of a merger or acquisition of this type, you must submit this mod notifying GSA that such a non-novated merger or acquisition has taken place.

Note that if the merger does require novation, a different modification Novation Agreement will be necessary.

  1. Log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Re-representation of Non-Novated Merger/Acquisition from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Re-representation of Non-Novated Merger/Acquisition subtype and click Submit Online.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue.

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Enter any details regarding the Re-representation of Non-Novated Merger/Acquisition in the box for a Modification Request. Provide a detailed description of the reason you are re-representing your merger or acquisition. You need to provide GSA with information regarding how the merger or acquisition does or does not impact your company. Specifically, you should note how the merger affects your business size classification, your socio-economic status, or any other information the CO may need to be aware of.

    6. Enter a detailed description of your Re-representation of Non-Novated Merger/Acquisition modification.

  6. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    7. Upload and Submit your modification

  7. When you are finished you will see a success message.

    8. Your mod has been submitted successfully.

  8. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: re-representation-of-business-size
page.title: Re-representation of Business Size
page.body:
Federal agencies often set aside contracts for small businesses with revenues under a specified threshold. As part of the contract offer process, your company was required to certify that it was or was not a small business. The Re-Representation of Business Size modification allows you to inform GSA if your company outgrows its small business designation, meaning it exceeds the revenue threshold that allows it to be categorized as a small business; or, inform GSA if your company size decreases and it now qualifies as a small business.

Businesses often fluctuate in size and, at times, may grow above the small business size standard or shrink below the threshold. In these such instances, you will need to modify your contract to re-represent your business size.

  1. Log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Re-representation of Business Size from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Re-representation of Business Size subtype and click Submit Online.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click Save and Continue.

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Enter any details regarding the Re-representation of Business Size in the box for a Modification Request. Provide the CO with the reason you are re-representing your company's business size. This information can be relatively high-level as you are going to need to provide supporting documentation in the Upload Documents section. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

    6. Enter a detailed description of your Re-representation of Business Size modification

  6. On the Information Saved message, click Continue.

    7. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen

  7. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    8. Upload and Submit your modification

  8. When you are finished you will see a success message.

    9. Your mod has been submitted successfully.

  9. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section on the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: revise-terms-and-conditions
page.title: Revise Terms and Conditions
page.body:
Terms and Conditions should be up-to-date at all times, as they ensure that parties of both sides of a transaction are aware of expectations and responsibilities.

  1. First, log into the eMod system and select your contract. (For more information, read the Getting Started with eMod Section.)

  2. Select Revise Terms and Conditions from the list of modification subtypes and click Submit Online.

    3. Select the Revise Terms and Conditions subtype and click 'Submit Online.'

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your corporate information and click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. Select the clause you wish to add from the drop-down menu. You must add at least one clause; multiple clauses can be revised, but only one at a time.

    • Note: For demonstration purposes, we will use the "C-FSS-411 Original" clause as an example. The clause(s) you choose may look different than the one presented here.

    Helpful Hint: When selecting a clause from the drop-down menu, you will notice each clause is named with a unique identifying number, and the word "Original," "Tailor," "Deviate," or "Regulate." These words indicate the version of the clause. Once a clause is added to the table, you will be able to view the title.

    Select the appropriate clause.

  6. Once you have made the applicable selection, click the Add button.

  7. The clause will appear in the table below. When you have added all of the necessary clauses, click Respond under the Action column.

    8. Click 'Respond' to address the clause.

  8. Complete the form by checking the appropriate box.

  9. If more details are necessary, click the Add button.

    10. Click the 'Add' button to include details about your mod.

  10. Enter the relevant information in the text boxes and click Save.

    11. Click 'Save' to add your changes.

  11. When you have added all of your information, you can click Preview to generate a PDF of your completed form.

    12. Click 'Preview' to generate a PDF that includes your information.

  12. Your PDF will be generated. You can open and/or save that document for later use.

    13. Your PDF will be generated.

  13. When you are satisfied with your responses, click Save.

  14. If you choose "Other Vendor Responses," you will be taken to an open text box. Provide the CO with a detailed description of your revision to the clause and click Save and Continue.

    • Note: In the case of revising your CSP-1 Terms and Conditions, read the Update/Revise Commercial Sales Practice section.

    Enter a detailed description of your modification.

  15. Back on the Revise Clause/Terms and Conditions page, you should see the status of each clause is now "Completed." When you have finished all clauses, click Save and Continue.

    16. Click 'Save and Continue' when you have finished all clauses.

  16. On the Information Saved screen, click Continue.

    17. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  17. Next, you have the opportunity to upload documents in support of this modification on the Upload Documents screen. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

  18. Click Upload under the Action column of the "Vendor Defined" type.

    19. Upload your supporting documentation.

  19. Click on the Browse button to locate the file you wish you upload, then type the name of the document into the corresponding text box and click the Upload This Document button.

    20. Click on the 'Upload' link.

  20. On the next screen, you will see that your document has been successfully uploaded. Click the Save and Continue button.

    • Note: If you want to upload more supporting documentation, click on the Upload Additional link under the Action column.

  21. When you have uploaded all documentation, click Save and Continue.

    22. Click 'Save and Continue.'

  22. On the Information Saved screen, click Continue.

    23. Click 'Continue.'

  23. If you are satisfied with your modification, click Yes on the Confirmation screen.

    • Note: You will have one last chance to review your modifications before the final submission.

    Click 'Yes' on the Information Saved screen.

  24. This is the screen where you can review your documents before submitting your mod. Answer the question about Disclaimers by selecting the Yes radio button, then click Continue.

    25. Review your modifications and click 'Continue.'

  25. You will see that your mod has been successfully submitted.

    26. Your eMod was submitted.

page.name: subcontracting-modification
page.title: Subcontracting Modification
page.body:
A Subcontracting Plan is required on a contract under certain situations. Generally, the Federal Acquisition Regulations (FAR) require a subcontracting plan from a Contractor classified as "Other than Small Business" when the actual sales of a contract exceed the $650,000 threshold (for contracts awarded on or after October 1, 2010) or the $550,000 threshold (for contracts awarded prior to October 1, 2010). In such a case, an informational message will appear on the My Modifications page as shown below.

  1. Create a Subcontracting Mod by selecting the contract and clicking Select Contract.

    2. A message will notify you if a Subcontracting Plan becomes required.

  2. Select the subtype "Incorporate Subcontracting Plan (SubK)" and click the Submit Online button at the bottom of the page.

    3. Select the Subcontract Plan modification.

  3. Verify your corporate information and click Save and Continue.

    4. Verify your Corporate Information and click 'Save and Continue.'

  4. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    5. Click 'Continue' on the Information Saved screen.

  5. You will be presented with the options to create or upload your subcontracting plan. If you already have a subcontracting plan, choose from the first set of options which will allow you to upload either a Master, or Commercial Plan. If you do not have a subcontracting plan, the second option will guide you through the steps to create one. Select either Individual Plan or Commercial Plan, then click Save Plan Type.

    6. Select the Subcontracting Plan type.

    Key Concept: "Commercial Plans" cover a vendor's fiscal year and applies to the entire production of commercial items sold by either the entire company or a portion thereof. It applies both for commercial and government business and affects all government contracts in the applicable year. "Individual Plans" cover an entire contract period and apply to one contract specifically.

  6. After selecting which subcontracting plan you wish to create, you will see an overview screen with each subsection of the subcontracting plan and its status. For the purpose of this example, we will walk through an Individual Plan. To begin, click Respond by the first section, Identification Data.

    Click the 'Respond' button by Identification Plan.

  7. Enter a detailed description of your Supplies/Services in the textbox. Next, enter your Place of Performance. Finally, the Estimated Contract Value from the Base Period to all of the Option Periods. Click the Save button and click Next.

    8. Enter your Description and Estimated Contract Values.

  8. The Goals section is where you state what percent of the contract value you intend to designate for the various subcontracting categories. Begin by clicking Add under the action column.

    9. Click the 'Add' link under your Base period goals.

  9. You will need to enter the Total Dollars to be Subcontracted, which will be the sum of your Large Business Goals and All SmallBusiness Goals. When filling out the Large Business goals, you will find the system will automatically complete either the percentage or dollar amount, depending on which you choose to fill out. This will help you along the way ensure you are doing the proper math and that everything adds up.

    10. Fill in your Base Period Subcontracting Goals

  10. Next, fill in the Small Business Type goals. These goals should be thought of independently, not as values that equal your All Small Business goal. As there may be instances where subcontractors qualify for multiple designations, each of the Small Business Types could add up beyond the total of the All Small Business goal. When you are finished click Save, then Next to move on.

    11. Fill in your Small Business Type Subcontracting Goals.

  11. You will see the subcontracting values reflected in the Goals chart. If you wish to fill any subsequent Option periods with the same goals as the Base period, click the Copy link; otherwise, skip to 15 below.

    12. If applicable, you can copy your goals from the Base period to fill in subsequent Option periods.

  12. The Base period's values will be copied onto the Option periods you select. When you have made your selections click Copy then Next.

    13. If applicable, select the periods to which you wants to copy your Base Period Small Business Type Goals

  13. The Goals chart will now have the matching values where you chose to replicate the Base year's values. You also have the ability to Edit or Delete each Option Year.

    14. You will now be able to see your goals reflected in the Goals table

  14. To select which Supplies or Services are to be subcontracted, click the Add button.

    15. Click 'Add' to select which Supplies or Services are to be subcontracted.

  15. Identify the Supply or Service to be subcontracted and select which type of subcontractor will be leveraged. When you have finished click Save and continue entries as applicable. When you are finished click Next.

    16. Enter the Supply or Services and their applicable designations.

  16. The List of Supplies or Services will now display your entries and corresponding eligible subcontracting types with the ability to Edit or Delete each entry.

    17. The Services or Supplies will now display in the Services/Supplies table.

  17. Next, using evidence (for example, historical data, experience, or research) explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals in Section C.

    18. Explain how your goals were established and justify any particularly low goals.

  18. Enter a detailed description on how your company plans to identify potential partners to meet your subcontracting goals in Section D.

    19. Enter a detailed description on how your company plans to identify potential partners to meet your subcontracting goals.

  19. Finally, in Section E, state whether indirect costs have been included in the subcontracting goals. If they have been accounted for, explain the methodology used to calculate these costs in the textbox below. When you are finished click Save then Next.

    20. State whether indirect costs have been included in the subcontracting goals, account for the calculation then click 'Save' to move on.

  20. You will be taken to the Program Administrator screen. You cannot add this information directly in the Subcontracting Plan utility but in the Terms and Conditions section. The Subcontracting Plan generates the associated points of contact there. Click the Terms and Conditions link on the left-hand navigation menu.

    21. Click the Administrative link on the left nav to enter your Admin Point of Contact.

  21. On the Terms and Conditions screen, you will be taken to the Point of Contacts Information entry screen. Enter your administrators information then click Add Point of Contact Information.

    22. Enter your administrators information and click 'Add Point of Contact Information.'

  22. After adding your Subcontracting Plan Point of Contact, navigate back to the Subcontracting Plan interface by using the navigation on the left. Click SubContracting Plan.

    23. Click the SubContracting Plan navigation link on the left.

  23. When you return to the previously blank screen, you will notice the Point of Contact details are now being displayed.

    24. When you return to the previously blank screen you will notice the Point of Contact details are now being displayed

  24. Next you will need to identify the duties of the the Subcontracting Plan administrator. One through five are required by the FAR. Select the applicable functions, meant to ensure effective implementation of the subcontracting plan. Identify any additional measures in the textbox at the end of the list. When you are finished click Save then Next to continue forward.

    25. Select the applicable Subcontracting Plan administrator.

  25. The Equitable Opportunity section summarizes your businesses efforts to ensure equitable opportunity and competition for small business, including outreach efforts as well as internal programs designed for purchasing personnel. Check all applicable boxes and describe additional efforts in the textbox provided. Click Save before clicking Next to continue on.

    26. Select the applicable Equitable Opportunities your business plans to pursue.

  26. The Clause Inclusion and Flow Down section contains the assurance that all subcontracts in excess of $650,000 ($1,500,000 for construction) adopt a plan which offers further subcontracting opportunities. You must agree to this by checking the box, then clicking Save before clicking Next.

    27. Check the box agreeing to Assurances of Clause Inclusion and Flow Down.

  27. The Reporting and Cooperation section contains assurances required by the FAR that all contractors will submit various forms of reports, including a timetable for Individual Subcontract Reports. All contractors must agree to this. Then click Save before clicking Next.

    28. Check the box agreeing to Reporting and Cooperation.

  28. In the Record Keeping section, confirm your intent to maintain records throughout the course of the Subcontracting Plan. Provide evidence of your ability to comply with Record Keeping standards using the text box following number 7 of this section. Click Save and Continue when you are finished.

    29. Agree to Record Keeping standards, provide evidence of your ability, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  29. In the Statutory Requirements section, confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click Save and Continue.

    30. Confirm your intent to comply with FAR requirements, then click 'Save and Continue.'

  30. The final section is the Good Faith Effort. You must give a detailed outline on the steps your company plans to take to achieve your subcontracting goals in good faith. When you have finished, click Save.

    31. Check the box agreeing to the Determination of Good Faith effort.

  31. Once you have finished the Good Faith Effort you have finished the Subcontracting Plan utility. You will see a message saying your Good Faith Effort outline has been saved. In order to continue with your eOffer or eMod you must use the navigation on the left to proceed to the Upload Documents section.

    32. Navigate to Upload Documents with the navigation panel on the left.

  32. You will then be required to upload documents in support of this modification. Afterwards, you will have a chance for a final review of your eMod. (For more information read Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod.

    33. Upload and Submit your modification

  33. When you are finished you will see a success message.

    34. Your mod has been submitted successfully.

  34. You will notice your modification under the Submitted Modifications section of the My Modifications screen. For any information about the processes after submitting your eMod, read the Post-Submission of an eMod section.

page.name: update-revise-commercial-sales-practice
page.title: Update/Revise Commercial Sales Practice
page.body:
When you submitted your initial offer, you were asked to perform some projections as to how much business you had planned to do with the government. One of the solicitation documents that you were required to upload included the CSP-1.

You will notice that on some mods there is a section for Updating or Revise Commerical Sales Practice (CSP-1). Beginning, in August of 2013, all contract modifications that could potentially impact the CSP for your contract will include the ability to revise the existing CSP-1 that is associated with your contract. These primary mod types include the following:

  • Additions;

  • Deletions; and

  • Pricing.

The purpose of this section is to assist you in completing the electronic CSP-1 form.

  1. You will be alerted that exercising your current modification may require you to update your commercial sales practices (CSPs). If this is the case, answer Yes and click Save, and you will be taken to the CSP update or revise your CSPs. Note that the phrasing of this question will reflect the mod you are exercising and may look different from the screenshot.

    Helpful Hint: As of August 2013, certain mod types will require the submitter to upload CSP documentation. In addition, these mods will also include an optional electronic form that users may use to update the CSP information.

    Click Revise the Revise button to get started on your CSP

  2. On Question 1a, enter a dollar figure that reflects the the total sales of the product or service during the previous 12-month period or during the last fiscal year. In 1b, designate the 12-month period for which you are providing the dollar figure. If you feel that the dollar figure is not an appropriate measure for sales, provide your own measure of the sales of the item(s) in the free-form box.

    3. Enter your total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all options, for each SIN.

  3. For Question 2a, enter the total projected annual sales to the Federal Government under the contract for the contract term, excluding all option, for each SIN. Provide your best estimate for any resulting contracts.

    If you already hold an FSS contract for the SIN, enter the annual sales for the past 12 months under the contract. Use the free-form box in section 2b to add any additional notes or comments that you may find to be helpful to your CO.

    4. Enter the total project annual sales to the Government under the contract for each SIN offered.

  4. Question 3 asks you if, based on your discount policies, your prices are as good or better than prices offer to any other questions acquiring the same items, regardless of quantity or terms and conditions.

    5. Identify whether the concessions which you offer the government are equal to or better than the best price offered to customers.

  5. The next step is to identity the level at which you want to specify the discount or concession policy. This can be done at an Offer/Contract level or specified down to the individual SIN. In the case of line item EAS Schedules, those can be specified down to the line item level.

    6. Key Concept: The discount policy can only be specified at one level. You may not have a combination policy of both an Offer/Contract discount and a SIN level discount.

    Select the level at which you want to specify the discount/concession policy.

    Caution: You must complete and Save the initial Commercial Sales Practice page before you are able to enter your Discount Policy.

  6. Question 4a will allow you to specify the details of your discount policy, and the options here change depending on whether you have selected a discount/concession policy based on the Offer/Contract level or the SIN level. First though, you must work through the initial information on this screen. Upon saving, you will be able to enter further details.

    7. You will need to fill out this first page and save it before adding details to your Discount Policy.

  7. In Question 4b, answer whether or not any deviations from your written policies or standard CSP disclosed in 4a ever resulted in better discounts (lower prices) or concessions than indicated. If you answer Yes, include the following: discussion on any situations that lead to deviations from standard practice, an explanation of how often they occur, and the controls you employ to assure the integrity of your pricing. Examples of typical deviations may include, but are not limited to: one time goodwill discounts to charity organizations or to compensate an otherwise disgruntled customer; a limited sale of obsolete or damaged goods; the sale of sample goods to a new customer; or the sales of prototype goods for testing purposes.

    If deviations from your written policies or standard commercial sales practices disclosed in the chart on the Commercial Sales Practices Format are so significant and/or frequent that the Contracting Officer cannot establish whether the price(s) offered is fair and reasonable, then you may be asked to provide additional information. The Contracting Officer may ask for information to demonstrate that you have made substantial sales of the item(s) in the commercial market consistent with the information reflected on the chart on the Commercial Sales Practice Format, a description of the conditions surrounding those sales deviations, or other information that may be necessary in order for the Contracting Officer to determine whether your offered price(s) is fair and reasonable. In cases where additional information is requested, the Contracting Officer will target the request in order to limit the submission of data to that needed to establish the reasonableness of the offered price.

    When you have completed all fields, click Save.

    8. Answer the question on deviations.

  8. The screen will update whether you have chosen to specify your discount/concession policy at the Offer/Contract level or at the SIN level.

    If you chose the Offer/Contract level you can specify your discount in terms of a discount or a markup/build out.

  9. A discount is, plainly, a discount from the original price.

    A mark up is based on the markup over cost (e.g. a 5% markup over the manufacturer's catalog price). This is common for dealer/resellers. Imagine your company is a dealer/reseller of widgets. The manufacturer catalog price that you pay for the widgets is $10 per widget. The price you are offering GSA is a 5% markup on the price you pay the manufacturer or $10.50.

    A buildup is derived from a buildup of individual costs. Your proposed GSA price is derived by totaling the individual cost elements that it takes to produce your product or service, and then adding an amount for profit. Profit, or fee, is usually expressed as a percentage of the cost elements. Your GSA proposed price will typically be a reduced profit or fee applied to the cost elements (e.g. labor + general & administrative + overhead + 5% profit = proposed GSA labor rate).

    Click Update Basis.

    10. To select your basis, click 'Update Basis.'

  10. You will be taken to a screen to select the basis for your policy with more detailed descriptions of your options. Choose your basis and click Save.

    11. Select your basis and click 'Save.'

  11. If your discount policy is at the SIN level, you will be able to define the basis for each SIN discount policy. You will see your SINS listed below. Click Update Basis to continue.

    12. Click 'Update Basis.'

  12. For each SIN you will be able to choose whether the basis for the CSP is Discount or Markup/Build Out. Make your choices and click Save.

    13. Select your basis and click 'Save.'

  13. You will be taken back to the updated CSP creation screen. You will now be able to add your discount policy. If you wish to change the level of your specificity on your discount policy, click Update Level; otherwise, click Add Discount Policy to enter your discount/concession information.

    14. Click 'Add Discount Policy.'

  14. You will be taken to the Discount Policy / Concession Terms interface to enter your policy details. Note that if you selected a SIN or Line Item Policy, you will be able to specify which ones to which the discount applies and that these fields will be absent for an Offer/Contract level discount policy.

    15. Discount Policy / Concession Terms Page.

    Use the following information to complete each column of the chart:

    Customer: Customer is the customer (e.g., Company XYZ) or category of customer (e.g., dealers, distributors, State, County, City and Local Governments, etc.) who receive the terms being disclosed.

    Discount: Provide in this column any basic discount offered this customer. A basic discount is any discount offered without regard for quantity (e.g., for a quantity of one). If you do not offer any basic discounts, insert "NONE."

    Quantity/Volume: Provide in this column any quantity or volume discounts offered this customer. For example, a discount of 10% is offered when 20+ units are purchased, OR a discount of 10% is offered when the net order exceeds $20,000.00. This discount is exclusive of any Basic Discount offered.

    FOB Terms: Provide the FOB Terms (Freight Terms) offered this customer. For example, FOB Origin (Plant), FOB Origin Freight Prepaid and Allowed, or FOB Destination.

    Concessions: Provide in the column any other terms or conditions, not previously listed, which are offered to this category of customer. For example, any prompt-payment terms, aggregate discount terms, enhanced or additional services offered, etc.

    More detailed instructions and information can also be found by clicking the link directly above question 4 on the CSP-1.

    The link about question 4a has a wealth of information on your CSP.

    When you are finished, click Save to return to the main CSP page.

  15. You will now see the discount policy information added to the Discount Policy table, where you can Edit or Delete the policy as needed.

    16. Your discount policy has been added

  16. If applicable, you may also add multiple policies by clicking Add Discount Policy.

    17. You can add multiple discount policies.

  17. When you are satisfied with your Commercial Sales Practice, click Save under the textbox provided in 4b.

    18. When you are satisfied with your CSP, click Save

page.name: uploading-documents-submitting-your-emod
page.title: Uploading Documents & Submitting Your eMod
page.body:
As noted in the steps for completing the modifications, you will be asked to upload any necessary documents upon the completion of entering all necessary information. The displayed list of documents to upload depends on the modification subtype. You will notice that certain documents are required. These will be identified with a red asterisk.

  1. Below is only an example. Each different function in eOffer/eMod will have its own specified set of required documents. Your screen and list of required documents may vary, however the process of uploading each document is the same. Begin by click the Upload link under the Actions column. In this example, a Labor Category Descriptions document is being uploaded.

    2. Helpful Hint: The "Vendor Defined" document type can be used to upload any optional documents you wish to include with your modification.

    Click the 'Upload' link to begin.

  2. The type of document is defined from your previous selection. Click Browse and locate the document on your computer that needs to be uploaded.

    3. Select the file to be uploaded.

  3. Give your document a meaningful title and click Upload This Document.

    4. Give your document a meaningful title and click Upload This Document

  4. On the Upload Documents screen, the document will be shown as "Uploaded."" There is the option to delete the uploaded document as well.

    5. The document has been uploaded.

  5. Repeat these steps as necessary until all required and desired optional documents have been uploaded. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

    6. When you have uploaded all of the documents, click 'Save and Continue.'

  6. On the Information Saved message click Continue.

    7. On the Information Saved message, click 'Continue.'

  7. The next screen asks if you are ready to submit the eMod. You will have one final opportunity after this to review your submission. When you are ready to submit the eMod, click Yes. This will take you to the Final Review of eMod screen.

    8. The ready to submit modification screen.

  8. The Final Review of eMod screen affords you one last opportunity to review the contents of your modification. Take the time to review your documents. Read the disclaimer and ensure you understand it properly before agreeing to it. When you are ready, select Yes and then click Continue.

    9. The Final Review screen.

  9. You will see a notification stating that the eMod was successfully submitted.

    10. The eMod has been successfully submitted.

  10. You may now exit the application by clicking the Exit link or going to the inbox by clicking the My eMods link.

    11. You may now exit the application.

page.name: post-submission-of-an-emod-overview
page.title: Post-Submission of an eMod Overview
page.body: There are several functions you can perform after you have submitted your eMod. In the instructions below, we let you know what you can and cannot do once your eMod has been submitted.

page.name: editing-an-emod
page.title: Editing an eMod
page.body:
You may decide, post-submission, that you wish to change some aspects of your modification. This can be easily accomplished using the eMod system.

  1. Go to the My Modifications homepage, locate the mod in the Submitted Modifications section, and click on the Edit Mod button under the Actions column.

    2. Click the 'Edit Mod' button.

  2. The Corporate Information page will be displayed.

  3. Select the section of the mod (from the upper-left menu) that needs to be edited.

    4. Select the section on the left side navigation.

  4. Edit or update the mod information and click Save and Submit.

page.name: withdrawing-an-emod
page.title: Withdrawing an eMod
page.body:
You may decide, upon further reflection, that you would like to withdraw a previously submitted eMod. The system does allow for a modification to be withdrawn after the submission has been completed. To withdraw a mod, proceed with the following steps:

  1. Locate the Mod in the Submitted Modifications section and click on the Withdraw Mod button which appears under the Actions column.

    2. Click the 'Withdraw Mod' button.

  2. A confirmation page will appear. Click Yes to withdraw the modification.

  3. The mod status displays as "Withdrawn." The mod can still be viewed for future reference.

    4. The status will change to "Withdrawn."

page.name: splitting-emod
page.title: Splitting eMod
page.body:
The Contracting Officer assigned to a particular offer has the ability to "split" the original mod into two. The purpose is to separate modification(s) which can be processed in a shorter time versus modification(s) which may take longer.

Caution: Important to note is that splitting an eMod refers to a function performed by a GSA CO or CS; it is not something you, as a vendor, can do. You will see the results of the split, but you are not the one actually performing the "splitting."

This expedites the overall process. The original mod is displayed along with the two new "split" mods. A notification is sent to the vendor indicating that the mod has been split. The action can be viewed on the My modifications page as shown below. Note that the original mod is not editable. It can only be viewed.

Once split, you will only be able to view the original mod, not edit it.

page.name: responding-to-a-clarification-request
page.title: Responding to a Clarification Request
page.body:
If the CO has questions regarding the eMod, a clarification email request is submitted to the vendor along with a Clarification Letter attached as shown below.

The vendor will receive an email requesting clarification.

  1. Upon receipt of a Clarification email, log into eMod.

  2. In Submitted Modifications, the status of that particular eMod will read "Provide Clarification."

  3. Click on that link.

    4. Click the 'Provide Clarification' link.

  4. The "Exception Contract Clauses submitted by the vendor" will be displayed.

  5. To view the history of clarifications, click on the View History link and the "History of Negotiations" will be listed.

  6. To respond to a clarification request, click on the Respond link.

    7. Click the 'Respond' link.

  7. The Request for Clarification screen will open up. Add your response in the bottom textbox and click Save to Draft.

    8. Review the CO/CS comments and revise the exception text.

  8. On the next screen, the status will show as "Completed."

  9. Click Submit Response.

    10. The status will show as "Completed."

  10. A success message will be displayed.

The vendor receives confirmation of the submission while the CO is notified that the vendor has responded to the request. The status of the mod changes back to "In Progress" on the My Modifications page. When approved, the status would change to "Approved."

page.name: esigning-an-emod
page.title: eSigning an eMod
page.body:
After the modification(s) has been approved by the Contracting Officer, the mod will appear within the Signed Modifications category with the "Status" indicating Ready for Vendor eSign.

  1. Choose the appropriate action based on whether the mod or the Package should be viewed or the Package should be signed.

  2. If ready to sign, click Sign Package.

    3. When the mod status show it is ready to be esigned, click the 'Sign Package' button.

  3. You will be presented with the option to Review and Accept the mod or to Reject eMo. Click the Review and Accept link to view the contents of the mod.

    4. Click Review and Accept to view the eMod

  4. Review the document by clicking the Review link, check the box confirming that the contract has been reviewed and click Continue.

    5. Review the contract and confirm to continue.

  5. After all documents have been reviewed, make your decision and click Sign eMod or Reject eMod.

    6. Sign the eMod to accept or reject it.

  6. Click the Confirm button; a success message will appear. In the Signed Modifications section the status of the eMod will change to "Awaiting CO esign". Once the CO signs, the contract package will be available for download.

    7. The modification status will change to Awaiting CO esign.

page.name: glossary
page.title: Glossary
page.body:
Term Definition

ACO

GSA Administrative Contracting Officer

Best Priced Customer

The customer or category of customers (commercial or government entity) in which your company offers the absolute best price, independent of terms and conditions, discounts, and/or concessions.

Central Intake Desks (CIDs)

FAS established a transformational process for MAS Contract Administration: the establishment of Central Intake Desks (CID). A CID is located at each MAS Acquisition Center for the receipt of all incoming Paper and Email Modification Requests.

Clause Exception

Vendor submitting contract proposals under the General Services Administration's Multiple Award Schedules (MAS) Program may specify Exception to a Solicitation Clause. The PCO may Approve, Reject or Request Clarification for a particular Clause Exception.

Contract Load

Several windows/screens in the Client Server Application, FSS Online within the PR module used to load and display Contract information including Vendor Clause Exceptions.

Contracting Professionals

Refers to both Contracting Officers and Contracting Specialists access and review electronic offers (e-Offers) and modifications (e-Mods) submitted by vendors via the FSS-19 system.

Contractor Warranty

The Contractor Warranty is the warranty your company offers in addition to the manufacturer's warranty. It can be established at the SIN level only and will be applied to all products under that SIN.

CORS

Contract Officer Review System

Delivery (Lead) Time Code

Use this field to identify the method in which your company determines delivery lead time.

The choices are as follows:

  • AF - time delivered after receipt of order
  • AE - time shipped after receipt
  • AX - award date to completion date

Delivery (Lead) Time Days

The number of days it will take for the product to meet the established delivery (lead) time code. This field is for defining the numerical value only.

For example, if you selected AE for Delivery (Lead) Time Days and enter 5 days, then the expectation is the product will ship (leave your company) five (5) days after you receive the order.

Discounts End Range

The end range is the point at which a quantity or volume discount ends.

For example, if you offer a 10% discount for orders of 1,000 units to 1,999 units, this value would be "1,999." Each discount must have a start range and an end range.

Discount Offered to Best Priced Customer

The best discount (expressed by percentage) that your company offers a product to the customer identified as the Best Priced Customer.

For example, if you offer your best price customer a 10% discount, you should enter "10" in this field.

Discounts Start Range

The start range is the point at which a quantity or volume discount begins. For example, if you offer a 10% discount for orders of 1,000 units to 1,999 units, this value would be "1,000." Each discount must have a start range and an end range.

ECF

Electronic Contract File

eCMS

Electronic Contract Management System: This system enables paperless process for Solicitations, Vendor Submission of Proposals, Bid Evaluation, Award Determination, Contract writing, Contract Management processes, as well as establishing and enforcing standard Acquisition practices and policies department-wide.

eOffer/eMod

eOffer/eMod web-based applications that allow companies to electronically prepare and submit Contract Proposals and Contract Modifications under the General Services Administration's Multiple Award Schedules (MAS) Program. The General Services Administration launched eOffer and eMod as the paperless means to streamline the Contract Award and Modification processes in May and July of 2004, respectively.

FAS CIO

GSA Federal Acquisition Service - Chief Information Officer.

FBO

Federal Business Opportunities (FedBizOpps) - Is a GSA operated website that contains all federal solicitation information.

FPDS-NG

Federal Procurement Data System - Next Generation (FPDS-NG): This system stores Contract and Order information. FAS automatically transmits all legacy FSS records regardless of value. Every modification to that Contract and/or Order must be report to the FPDS-NG system. FPDS-NG's data are used to create recurring and special Reports to the President, Congress, Government Accountability Office, federal executive agencies, and the general public. It is extremely important that data contained in FPDS-NG is accurate, complete, and submitted in a timely manner.

FPL

Formatted Price List: Piloted by Financial And Business Solutions (FABS) schedule 520, part of an initiative by GSA to streamline the Electronic Price List process, and to create a database in which Customer Agencies can search for their desired services and compare pricing.

FSSI

Federal Strategic Sourcing Initiative: The result of a partnership between GSA and the US Department of Treasury, responding to an Office of Management and Budget and Office of Federal Procurement Policy Request requiring all Agencies to identify Commodities to be Purchased more efficiently through strategic sourcing.

IL 2011-09

Instructional Letter 2011-09 was memo released by the GSA Office of Acquisition Management outlining new instructions for the implementation of the Requirement for Subcontracting Plans.

IOA

Industrial Operations Analyst.

ISO 3166

International Organization of Standardization (ISO) ISO 3166 is the international standard for country codes and codes for their subdivisions.

Line Item Level

This level is applicable when the vendor decides to define category(ies) at line item level.Vendor will be allowed to define each category separately for each product related line item within the offer. This feature can be best used when the vendor wants to uniquely define category(ies) for each product related line ­item.

List of categories that can be established at line ­item Level: Discounts, Delivery, Special Charges, Special Features, Accessories, Options, and Photos.

Manufacturer Name

The manufacturer name is the name of the entity that is the original manufacturer of the product. Honeywell, Samsung, and DeWalt are all examples of manufacturer names.

Manufacturer Part Number

The Manufacturer's Part Number (MPN) is the number created by and assigned to a product by the manufacturer. This field should be entered exactly as provided by the manufacturer, and should not be edited, truncated, or appended in any way.

An example of an MPN is: HSC0424PP.

MAS

Refers to Multiple Award Schedule (MAS) Program.

NAICS Code

North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) Codes are used by the government to classify business establishments according to type of economic activity.

Offer Level

This level is applicable when the vendor decides to define category(ies) at offer level and those descriptions will apply to all SINs within that offer, therefore, to all product related line items within those SINs. In this scenario, vendor will be entering the descriptions or categories only once that is at Offer level.

List of categories that can be established at Offer Level: Discounts, Delivery, and Zonal Pricing

Offer Registration System (ORS)

ORS is a web-based application that is used for Offer Registration, Tracking, and Awarding Contracts from GSA Schedules. It is the initial entry point where Contracts begin their lifecycle through the FSS-19 system. ORS is used by all Federal Acquisition Service (FAS) Centers as the standard Procurement system.

Online Content Management System (OCMS)

A web accessible Contract Management system used by FAS's Supplier Management Division. The system is used by Industrial Operations Analysts (IOAs) and Administrative Contracting Officers (ACOs) to document Contractor Assistance Visits (CAVs) and to prepare Contractor Report Cards.

Options

An option is a configurable element of a product, or a feature that may be chosen as an addition to, or replacement for, standard equipment and features.

Examples of options include but are not limited to: color, engine size, fabric type.

PCO

Procurement Contracting Officer (PCO) - is the only person who can bind the United States government to a contract with a vendor, limited to the extent of the authority delegated by the head of the Agency.

Product/Accessory Name

The product or accessory name is the name by which the product or accessory will be known. Use the name that the manufacturer has given to the product.

Examples: laptop bag, refrigerator, and drill.

SIP

Schedule Input Program - a proprietary software program provided by GSA to assist Contract holders with uploading their electronic catalog.

SIN Level

This level is applicable when the vendor decides to define category(ies) at SIN level.Vendor will be allowed to define each category separately for each SIN within the offer. All product related line ­items under the SIN will follow the description defined for that respective SIN. In this scenario, vendor will be entering the descriptions for each category for each SIN within the offer.

List of categories that can be established at SIN Level: Discounts, Delivery, and Contractor Warranty.

Unit of Issue

The unit of issue describes in what format, quantity, or packaging a product will be sold. The most common unit of issue is "each" (EA), but other examples are "box", "pack", "ream", or even "dozen".

UPC/ ISBN/ GTIN 14/ EAN 8/ EAN 13

A unique identification code that is assigned to a product by a governing organization named GS1 US. Manufacturers must apply for, and are assigned UPCs by this organization. The code is comprised of digits representing the manufacturer, and the product itself. UPCs can take several formats, ranging from 8 to 14 digits, depending on which format is being used. Examples of formats are European Article Number (EAN) 8, EAN-13, International Standard Book Number (ISBN), and Global Trade Identification Number (GTIN).

Most products submitted for sale on a Federal Supply Schedule will follow the UPC-A 12 character format. An example of a UPC-A is: 8-92685-00100-3

page.name: resources
page.title: Resources
page.body:
Below are a list of useful links and resources to help you in using eOffer/eMod.

Helpful Links for Using eOffer/eMod

Schedule Maintenance - Find out when maintenance is schedule for eOffer/eMod

Dun & Bradstreet - You must have a DUNS number to user the eOffer/eMod system

page.name: faq
page.title: FAQ
page.body:
How do I obtain a digital certificate?

A digital certificate can be obtained at http://eoffer.gsa.gov. Under the Before You Begin section, click on Digital Certificates. Once you have determined whether you want a certification from IdentTrust or Operational Research Consultants, click the corresponding link, read all information and click Get Certificate. Always remember your password, as GSA and the Digital Certificate Provider do not have access to it.

What is the Data Universal Number System Number?

A Data Universal Number System, or DUNS, number is a unique nine-digit identification number assigned to a business entity by Dun & Bradstreet. It is required to use the eOffer/eMod system and also needed when registering with the SAM database. The DUNS number assignment is free for all businesses required to register with the U.S. Federal government for contracts or grants.

How do I obtain a DUNS number?

Go to http://fedgov.dnb.com/webform. The Dun and Bradstreet homepage will be displayed. Click the option to request the DUNS number via the Web. From there you can either follow the instructions or select the option to request the number by phone.

How do I register with the System for Award Management?

You must create a User Account. Go to the SAM homepage: https://www.sam.gov/portal/public/SAM/. Click Create User Account. Choose either an Individual or System account. Under Individual Account Details, choose Create an Account. Simply follow all directions and fill out the Personal Information and Account information form fields. You will be asked to confirm and submit all information upon completion.

How do I attend a Pathway to Success Training presentation?

Vendors may attend either a live presentation or complete the Web-based presentation posted on the Vendor Support Center at http://vsc.gsa.gov under the Vendor Training tab.

page.name: special-charges
page.title: Special Charges
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/special_charges_lesson

book Instructions

  1. Within the Special Charges screen, first choose the SIN to which these charges apply using the SIN drop-down menu.

    2. Choose your SIN.

  2. Click the Select button.

    3. Click Select.

  3. Check the boxes for the charges that apply to your SIN.

    4. Check the applicable charges for your SIN.

  4. Click the Add Special Charges button.

    5. Click Add Special Charges.

page.name: special-features
page.title: Special Features
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/special_features_lesson

book Instructions

If you selected "Yes" to Special Features on the Wizard Management screen, you are required to complete this section. Here, you will select your Environmental and Special Features that will be incorporated into your final template.

Special Features allows you to account for environmental features and non-standard product features.

  1. Within the Special Features screen, first choose the SIN to which these features apply using the drop-down menu.

    2. Select your SIN.

  2. Click the Select button.

    3. Click the Select button.

  3. Check the boxes for the features that apply to your SIN under both the Environmental Features and Special Features headings.

    4. Check the applicable environmental and special features for your SIN.

  4. Click the Add Special Features button.

    5. Click Add Special Features.

  5. You will see the item(s) you have chosen in a table at the bottom of your screen.

    6. Your selections will appear in the table below.

  6. Click the Save and Continue button.

    7. Click Save and Continue.

page.name: discounts
page.title: Discounts
page.body:
If you selected "Yes" to Discounts on the Wizard Management screen, you are required to complete this section.

In this section, you will need to enter the discount(s) you offer under your selected SIN. You will need to enter the start and end range for the discount, as well as the percentage. You can add multiple discounts, but only one at a time.

  1. Within the Create Discount table, you will see a field called Start Range. This indicates the minimum number of items (greater than 1) that need to be ordered to initiate a discount.

    2. Begin by defining the start to your Discount quantity range.

  2. Next, fill in the text box for End Range. This indicates the maximum number of items ordered to fulfill a discount.

    3. Select the end range for your discount range.

  3. Enter the Discount % you will offer.

    4. Enter the discount percentage.

  4. If you have any discount conditions, add them in the text box.

    5. Enter the discount conditions of the range you defined.

  5. Click the Add Discount button.

    6. Click Add Discount.

  6. Your discount will be added to the Discount Listing table at the bottom of the screen.

    7. The Discount will appear below.

  7. Click the Save & Continue button.

    8. Click Save and Continue.

  8. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

    9. Click the Continue button.

page.name: delivery
page.title: Delivery
page.body:
This section is required and was automatically selected for you in the Wizard Management section.

  1. Some of the data you entered in previous tabs has been auto-populated into this tab. Double check that this information is correct before moving on.

    2. Note the auto-populated information.

  2. Make your delivery selection for CONUS (contiguous United States) from the drop-down menu.

    3. Make your delivery selection for CONUS.

    FOB stands for Free on Board. You will have two FOB delivery from which to choose: FOB Origin indicates shipping is paid by the seller, FOB Destination indicates shipping is paid by the buyer, and FOB No Delivery means the seller does not offer delivery to that state.

  3. Make your delivery selections for the remaining fields.

    4. Make selections for the remaining fields.

  4. Enter the Shipping Unit Weight.

    • The Shipping Unit Weight is the numerical measurement of the weight of the packaged product.

    Enter the Shipping Unit Weight.

  5. Enter the Shipping Package Cube.

    • The Shipping Package Cube is the size of the shipping package measured in cubic feet. This field is required when the Free on Board (FOB) point value is Origin (O).

    Enter the Shipping Package Cube.

  6. Click the Save Delivery button.

    7. Click Save Delivery.

  7. Click OK on the Product Confirmation pop-up message.

    8. Click OK.

page.name: contractor-warranty
page.title: Contractor Warranty
page.body:
If you selected "Yes" to Contractor Warranty on the Wizard Management screen, you will need to complete this section.

In this section, you will indicate the details of the Contractor Warranty offered under your SIN. Here, you will enter the warranty period and, if applicable, a description of the warranty.

  1. First, select your SIN from the drop-down menu.

    2. Select your SIN.

  2. Select the Warranty Period (day, month, year, or lifetime).

    3. Select your Warranty Period.

  3. Next, enter the Number of Warranty Periods in the text box. This indicates the period that the warranty covers. If you selected a warranty of "Lifetime," you would put "0" in this field.

    4. Enter the number of warranty periods.

  4. Enter your Warranty Description (if applicable).

    5. Enter the Warranty Description.

  5. Click the Add Contractor Warranty button.

    6. Click Add Contractor Warranty.

  6. Your warranty information will be displayed in a table at the bottom of your screen.

    7. Your warranty information will appear in a table.

  7. Click the Save and Continue button.

    8. When you are finished, click Save and Continue.

  8. On the Information Saved screen, click the Continue button.

    9. Click Continue on the Information Saved screen.

page.name: choosing-a-pricing-template
page.title: Choosing a Pricing Template
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/choosing_pricing_template_lesson

book Instructions

Before you make your selection for a pricing template, you must have completed each section on your left-hand navigational menu. When you are ready to enter your pricing data, you have three templates from which to choose. The method you select is dependent upon the number of items you need to enter, and your preference to work on or offline.

On this screen, you will see three options: Download/Upload Template, On-Screen Data Entry, and Electronic Data Interchange (EDI).

A look at the Capture and Generate Pricing main screen.

  1. Choose your method for entering details for product-related line items.

    1. Download/Upload Template

      • This method allows you to download an Excel template created by the system and work on it offline. After entering your data, you will need to upload the file back into the system to validate against any errors. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.

        • Download a template.

    2. On-Screen Data Entry

      • This method allows you enter product information into the template within the system. You are required to be online while working in this template. This method is best for entering 100 items or fewer.

        • Enter your data online.

    3. Electronic Data Interchange (EDI)

      • This method allows you to download a template created by the system and work on it offline. You will be required to generate a transaction key and use it in the EDI system to upload your files. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.

        • Work on a template offline.

  2. Select the pricing template that best suits your needs by clicking on the button under the option you choose.

page.name: choosing-a-pricing-template-ppr
page.title: Choosing a Pricing Template
page.body:
Start the interactive lesson below or scroll down for the unabridged step-by-step-instructions.

book Interactive Lesson

presentation/choosing_pricing_template_lesson

book Instructions

Before you make your selection for a pricing template, you must have completed each section on your left-hand navigational menu. When you are ready to enter your pricing data, you have three templates from which to choose. The method you select is dependent upon the number of items you need to enter, and your preference to work on or offline.

On this screen, you will see three options: Download/Upload Template, On-Screen Data Entry, and Electronic Data Interchange (EDI).

A look at the Capture and Generate Pricing main screen.

  1. Choose your method for entering details for product-related line items.

    1. Download/Upload Template

      • This method allows you to download an Excel template created by the system and work on it offline. After entering your data, you will need to upload the file back into the system to validate against any errors. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.

        • Download a template.

    2. On-Screen Data Entry

      • This method allows you enter product information into the template within the system. You are required to be online while working in this template. This method is best for entering 100 items or fewer.

        • Enter your data online.

    3. Electronic Data Interchange (EDI)

      • This method allows you to download a template created by the system and work on it offline. You will be required to generate a transaction key and use it in the EDI system to upload your files. This method is best for entering 100 or more items.
